book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
I have now helped run more than fifty crowdfunding
campaigns in varying capacities, nearly all of which
have met and far exceeded their fundraising goals. My
crowdfunding consulting company, Vann Alexandra,
officially incorporated in April 2014.
Crowdfunding campaigns can be really rewarding
(literally and figuratively), but I’m here to warn you that
they are also a potential minefield. Crowdfunding has
changed so much in the short time since Indiegogo
and Kickstarter started out (in 2008 and 2009
respectively). We’ve gone from the era when it was all
about mom-and-pop indie creatives and visionaries
raising a few thousand dollars online, to a point in time
when crowdfunding platforms are being flooded with
campaigns from major celebrities and even Fortune
500 companies. It’s no longer possible to throw your
idea online and expect the money to magically begin
to flow; there’s too much competition for that. Now
you need a serious plan.
More importantly, you need a guide—someone
who’s been in the trenches and helped her clients
come out on top. Or her book (the one you’re
reading!). Since officially launching Vann Alexandra,
I’ve spent every working day running campaigns, and
I’ve learned what works and what doesn’t. More than
anything, I’ve mastered how to communicate and
connect with people online.
This is a space that’s getting more crowded all the
time—not just with projects but with funding
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
platforms, too. Most of the campaigns I’ve managed
have been on Kickstarter, where I got my start.
Kickstarter’s all-or-nothing funding model can be scary
and risky, but it also reflects real life: you can’t raise
half what you need to manufacture your product and
still succeed; you need the full amount you set out to
raise. It’s a daring prospect, but it creates a huge
sense of urgency.
I’ve also run my share of Indiegogo campaigns.
While Kickstarter has declared that they’re not a store,
Indiegogo is embracing the e-commerce side of
crowdfunding, which I find compelling. They’ve added
features like their “InDemand” program, which allows
successful campaigners to keep funding even after
campaigns end. As InDemand gains more traction I
expect more creators will use this to maximize sales
over time.
Although we have used Kickstarter and Indiegogo
for our campaigns, there are so many other platforms:
GoFundMe, Patreon, PledgeMusic, RocketHub, and
Fundable, to name a few. But while the platforms
continue to evolve (and new ones continue to crop
up), the heart of crowdfunding remains the same: it’s
all about making an authentic connection with your
crowd. That’s become my specialty, and it’s what I’ll
show you how to do in this book, so you can take
these lessons and apply them to any launch on any
platform—even beyond crowdfunding, in fact. That
includes a launch on your own platform, like your
company website.
What I have learned is not just how to raise
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
awareness for projects online, but how to turn that
awareness into money. Once you’ve read this book,
you’ll have no hesitation about how to kickstart an
idea of your own. You’ll know how it works and have
the capacity to maximize your chance of success
beyond what you’ve even imagined.
This book will give you the tools not only to run your
own successful crowdfunding campaigns, but also to
build, launch, and grow your brand and your business.
You’ll know how to connect with your audience,
promote yourself and your ideas, and stand out online,
on social media, and in the press. You’ll have an
understanding of what it takes to establish your brand
and find your niche in the world. You’ll feel expert at
connecting and communicating with people online.
And perhaps most importantly, you’ll have gained the
inspiration and confidence to forge your own path. My
hope for this book is that it will empower you,
showing you that you can start something from
scratch and that really, anything is possible.
Okay, let’s dig in! To get you started, here are the
top ten questions you need to be able to answer
before you run a crowdfunding campaign:
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
1. WHO’S MY TARGET AUDIENCE?
The answer to this question will inform how you tell
your project’s story—from the video to the campaign
page to the rewards. Knowing who you’re speaking to
will determine how you speak. This is the foundation
of your project’s success. It will also determine your
outreach strategy—who might be likely to cover you in
the press and support you on social media and
beyond.
• Chapter 1 is the story of how I learned the
value of tapping into a built-in audience (plus
tips for how to build your own).
• Chapter 4 covers how to make a great
campaign page.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
2. HAS THERE BEEN A MARKET TEST?
Crowdfunding, in many ways, is a market test: you get
to see how the market responds to your idea. It’s
pretty amazing. But I have seen that some of the most
successful projects often have some kind of market
test well before the crowdfunding phase. Your pre-
launch test could be a website that catches fire, press
pieces that start a conversation on social media,
customer surveys that show positive results, or lots of
buzz in a community asking for the very thing you’re
making.
• Chapter 3 tells the story of how I first
discovered the power of a market test.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
3. HOW WILL I REACH MY TARGET AUDIENCE?
You might have a great product and a great campaign,
but all your hard work and preparation won’t matter if
your audience can’t find it. Do you have an active
mailing list? Are you engaged with people online? Do
you have a network of contacts—from family,
colleagues, and friends to influencers (respected
individuals in your target industry who have a large,
loyal fan base online) or maybe even a few big names
who could be involved? Have you secured any
coverage in the media outlets your target audience
follows?
• Chapter 7 covers everything you need to
know about getting press and handling
social media.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
4. WHAT’S MY TIMELINE?
Please, please don’t launch before you’re really ready.
I usually tell my clients that the ideal is at least eight
weeks to prepare before launching, but it totally
depends on how much you have done so far. If
there’s no urgency, focus on building a super strong
mailing list well before that. Another rule of thumb I
try to go by is this: don’t launch a campaign from
November to January. It’s the holiday season, and
many people are away from their computers. Not to
mention, unless your product is ready to ship
immediately, backers don’t want to pledge for a
reward that will come to them months after the
holidays. I like to do 30-day campaigns that start on a
Tuesday morning; campaigns that are 30 days or less
perform better, according to Kickstarter, and I find we
can better capture people’s attention early in the
week.
• The Resources section at the end of this
book includes a full pre- and post-launch
sample schedule.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
5. WHAT’S MY BUDGET?
It’s not just the amount you need to fund your project;
there are also the costs of building the campaign
itself: making the video; producing all kinds of written
and visual content; working with a designer; spending
time on press research, social media, and audience
building; creating and shipping rewards; campaign
platform fees; taxes; and a buffer for anything
unexpected that could go wrong.
• Chapter 6 explains how to budget.
• The Resources section includes a budget
worksheet.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
6. ARE MY VIDEO AND CAMPAIGN PAGE OPTIMIZED?
Competition is tough, no matter what industry you’re
in. Your story needs to be communicated in a way
that’s clear, concise, and visual. Creating a
crowdfunding campaign is an exercise in branding:
you need to know your mission, voice, style, and
visual identity. It needs to look and sound exceptional.
• Chapters 2 and 4 are dedicated to showing
you how to do all this and more.
• Chapter 5 is a great story about how a pre-
campaign rebranding exercise set a project
up for success.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
7. WHAT REWARDS WILL I OFFER?
This is a huge component of your project—and an all-
too-common stumbling block for many creators. It’s
so important to consider who your audience is when
determining appealing rewards. And budgeting for
rewards production, shipping, and the logistics
involved is a big undertaking.
• Chapter 6 will give you budgeting tips and
ideas for rewards.
• Chapter 8 is about a campaign that had
some of my favorite rewards (and an
awesome and unusual rewards strategy).
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
8. WHAT’S MY SOCIAL MEDIA STRATEGY?
In addition to creating social media accounts, building
up an audience, and planning engaging content to
share, we develop an influencer strategy where we
enlist individuals with large social media followings for
support online. It’s extremely effective.
• Chapter 3 goes in-depth about how we
created our first influencer campaign.
• Chapter 7 breaks down exactly how to do
this.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
9. WHAT’S MY PRESS STRATEGY?
Press can get you the attention you need. Planning
and researching a press strategy is a pre-launch
necessity. You’ll want to create a wish list of press
outlets that might cover your campaign and make sure
to find actual email addresses so you can pitch
journalists directly.
• Chapter 7 will lead you through how to
develop a press strategy.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
10. AM I PREPARED FOR WHAT HAPPENS AFTER THE
CAMPAIGN ENDS?
The real work begins when your crowdfunding
campaign ends. Now that you have the money you
asked for, it’s time to get to work. You also have to
get rewards into the hands of your backers efficiently
and within budget. (I almost always recommend
working with a fulfillment partner who can handle
product manufacturing and shipping.) On top of all
that, you have to think even bigger: Has your
campaign been so successful that it makes sense for
you to keep raising money? Are you prepared to start
a business?
• Chapter 6 dives into the challenges of
handling rewards fulfillment yourself.
• Chapter 9 offers post-campaign strategies I
recommend, from continued funding to
press and marketing.
• In the afterword, I pull back the curtain on
everything I learned from starting a business
myself.
Throughout this book, I’m going to show you how
to get people so excited about your big idea that
they’ll give you the money to make it happen. I’ll show
you what not to do, too. I’ve made a ton of mistakes
along the way, and I can help you avoid them. Above
all, I’ll show you how to connect with the crowd in the
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
digital age, how to get people to pay attention to you,
and beyond that—how to inspire them to action.
This book covers it all—real strategies, real stories,
and real how-tos. I’ve also included a Resources
section with a checklist and timeline, real examples of
press releases and emails, a list of great sites to use,
and more. I recommend reading the book beginning to
end, since it covers everything you’ll need to do for
your campaign, but you can also skip around if you
need to focus on a particular issue or phase. Here we
go!
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Chapter 1
Sex and Broadcasting: My First
Time
“What do you know about Kickstarter?”
There it was—the fateful question that came from a
coworker I barely knew as we filled up our coffee
cups in the office kitchen. Tim was an editor and
producer with another film production company
housed in the same space as the documentary
company where I was working. It was the spring of
2012 and I was spending a lot of my time writing grant
applications. So when Tim told me he was looking for
someone to help fundraise for his latest documentary,
I thought it was because he wanted me to write
grants for him. But no, it was for this thing called
Kickstarter.
“Hmm,” I started to answer, stalling a little.
“Kickstarter’s that new thing on the Internet, right?”
In fact, I had no clue what Kickstarter was.
“It’s a way to raise money on the Internet,” Tim
explained.
I played Tim off like I understood what he was
talking about. If I’d learned one thing in my early 20s,
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
it was that saying yes to a new challenge usually pays
off, even if you don’t know what the hell you’re doing.
So I decided to help Tim launch his Kickstarter.
The documentary Tim was making was about a
charmingly weird radio station based in New Jersey.
Tim cut together a great trailer, I wrote the campaign
page, and we launched early that summer, relentlessly
targeting the radio station’s existing fan base. By the
end of the 30-day campaign, we surpassed our
$50,000 goal and raised over $80,000.
Did that sound really easy? It wasn’t. It was hard. It
was terrifying. And also the best thing ever.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
CROWDFUNDING 101
First things first: in rewards-based crowdfunding,
project creators raise money for projects through
online pledges from backers, and in return, backers
get a reward. For example, in the film category, a
reward might be a copy of the film, a poster, dinner
with the director, or a name in the credits. What’s
really fascinating about rewards-based crowdfunding
is that backers are essentially donating to a project,
not investing in it. In the case of many crowdfunding
campaigns—like the ones that raise money for film
editing—backers are pledging to help make your
project happen, not necessarily to place an order on a
product.
Two widely used rewards-based crowdfunding
platforms are Kickstarter and Indiegogo, where
creators set a monetary goal to reach within a limited
period of time (for example, 30, 45, or 60 days). A
critical difference between Kickstarter and Indiegogo
is that funding on Kickstarter is always all-or-nothing. If
a creator raises only $49,000 toward a $50,000 goal
on Kickstarter, they get nothing. On the other hand, on
Indiegogo, creators can run a campaign with an all-or-
nothing “fixed” model or with flexible funding.
Flexible funding means creators keep the money they
raise, even if they don’t hit their target.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
A Note on Crowdfunding Terms
If you’re going to crowdfund, first you need to
know the language. Some crowdfunding terms
are specific to the platform you use. Kickstarter,
for instance, calls people who launch campaigns
“creators,” while Indiegogo calls them
“campaign owners.”
People who put money toward a project?
They’re “backers” on Kickstarter and
“contributors” on Indiegogo, and in exchange for
giving money to a campaign, you get a “reward”
on Kickstarter and a “perk” on Indiegogo.
Both platforms have been great to work with,
but since most of the campaigns I’ve run have
been on Kickstarter, I tend to use Kickstarter
terms. But don’t get hung up on language! Each
pair of terms basically means the same thing.
When clients come to me asking which platform to
use, I tell them it’s really up to them to determine
which one they are most comfortable with. Both
platforms can lead you to success, but if you’re
deciding between Indiegogo and Kickstarter, and you
know you need the flexible funding option, Indiegogo
is your only option. In my experience, though, most of
the campaigns I run actually can’t consider the flexible
model. They know the amount of funding they need
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
(to finish editing a film, to manufacture a product, to
produce their idea), and falling short of their goal
would mean that they couldn’t do what they set out
to. So whether they go with Kickstarter or Indiegogo
or another platform, I suggest the all-or-nothing model.
Both Kickstarter and Indiegogo ask campaign
owners to abide by their terms of use in order to use
the platform. The terms of use include information
about guidelines, policies, eligibility (for example, you
must be at least 18 years old), prohibited rewards, and
more. Both sites provide plenty of information about
their rules and approval processes, so be sure to
check out the fine print on each respective platform in
advance of preparing your campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WFM WHO?
When Tim showed me the trailer for the documentary
he wanted to kickstart, Sex and Broadcasting
(originally titled Freeform or Death), I was immediately
obsessed. The film was going to be about WFMU, a
formatless, listener-supported, noncommercial radio
station broadcasting out of Jersey City, New Jersey.
It’s the longest running freeform radio station in the
United States. “Freeform” means that DJs are given
complete control over what they play. WFMU’s
programming includes every kind of music you might
imagine, from what WFMU calls “flat-out
uncategorizable strangeness” to rock and roll, jazz,
electronica, hip-hop, punk rock, cooking instructions,
found sound, and much, much more.
The more I learned about WFMU, the more I fell in
love with its persistent independence and anti-
establishment ethos. It turns out I wasn’t the only
one. Over the years, WFMU had built up a strong cult
following. “Hands down WFMU is the greatest radio
station on the planet,” filmmaker Jim Jarmusch has
said. The Village Voice called it “the crown jewel of
New York independent radio.” Still, part of the story
Tim wanted to tell through the documentary was how,
year after year, WFMU struggles financially,
perpetually on the brink of shutting down.
Tim started shooting the documentary in 2009, at
the height of the Great Recession. The trailer was
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
captivating: in it, the station’s manager, Ken
Freedman, says that for the past twenty-five years
he’s been trying to keep the radio station alive. Ken is
the film’s lovable protagonist, and the movie is as
much about him as it is about the station. Later in the
trailer, Ken paces around the basement on a frantic
phone call saying, “We’re dead in the water—the
whole station is off the air!” We then see Ken in a
meeting where he tells his team that the station
probably won’t make it through the year.
Toward the end, Ken says, “I just want there to be a
WFMU… I want WFMU to exist as a place where
people can go who don’t fit in, where people can go to
find things that have been hidden. It’s a cause, it’s a
cultural outlet, it’s my family; it’s like my religion.”
Meanwhile, as part of a crazy stunt to help raise
money for the station, we see Ken strapping himself
into a chair with massive balloons attached, trying to
float into the air. The trailer ends as the chair starts to
lift off the ground, but we viewers can’t tell what’s
going to happen. It’s poignant—and you really want to
find out whether the station will survive. I loved how
the trailer mirrored the concept of crowdfunding. I
saw Ken and WFMU as the passionate underdogs
who needed the support of the crowd to get off the
ground.
Tim had been working on the project for a few years
by the time I came on board to help crowdfund it. He
was shooting, directing, editing—doing everything by
himself. He’d first discovered WFMU in 1989 when he
moved to New York, and he’d fallen in love with the
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
spirit of the station and how it connected him to new
worlds of music. Later, he told Filmmaker magazine,
“I wanted to make a film about WFMU because, as a
filmmaker who constantly must try to find a balance
between art and commerce, the station serves as
both a beautiful example and a warning about the
sacrifice that is required.”
But the project was time-consuming and expensive.
Three years into his work, Tim had collected hundreds
of hours of footage, but he still needed to edit it and
complete the entire post-production process. He was
determined not to let the project fall by the wayside—
and he didn’t want to let WFMU down. He felt that if
he could bring the documentary into the world, not
only could he inspire people with WFMU’s story, but
he could call attention to the reality of the station’s
financial struggles and help keep it alive.
Now he needed money to make the film a reality.
That’s why he turned to Kickstarter.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PUTTING THE PROJECT ONLINE
After wrapping my head around crowdfunding and
Kickstarter, Tim and I got to work. Running a
crowdfunding campaign is like running a business, and
your campaign page is like your business’s website. It
houses everything—the story of your project, the
video, your project image, your biography as the
project’s creator, the rewards, an FAQ, a way to
update backers, and more. It’s a lot. And it needs to
be meticulously crafted in order to raise money.
As I began to find my way through the Kickstarter
process for Sex and Broadcasting, Tim and I started
filling in the basic fields required for any campaign.
• Project image: Tim had a really cool title card
designed for the film, which had the name
of the documentary in large, easy-to-read
type.
• Project title (60 characters or less): Our title
became: “Freeform or Death, a
documentary about WFMU.” We wanted it
to be short and include certain keywords so
it would be easily searchable: the title,
“documentary,” and “WFMU.”
• A short blurb about the project (135
characters or less): Kickstarter currently
limits the characters for this field, so Tim
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
and I wanted to pack a punch with just a
few words. We wrote: “Help us share the
story of New Jersey’s WFMU, the world’s
longest-running freeform radio station, in its
fight to stay alive.” (I don’t suggest using
the word “help” anymore. I think that it calls
too much attention to the fact that you’re
trying to raise money, which is never
exciting. Instead, make sure to describe
what the actual project is, and state the
most compelling thing about it.)
• Category (and a subcategory if you wish):
Ours was in the film category, under
documentary.
• Project location: Easy. New York, New York.
• Funding duration: 30 days. We had read that
Kickstarter says campaigns that are 30 days
or less are more successful, and my
experience since has borne this out. Short
campaigns are more effective because there
is less fundraising fatigue.
• Funding goal: $50,000. (The way we arrived
at that number is below.)
• Project collaborators: This feature didn’t
exist when we were working on Sex and
Broadcasting. But now, instead of having a
single creator in charge of a campaign, you
can add collaborators so your teammates
can also help edit your project.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Indiegogo has a similar set of components (the
character counts for the title and taglines are different)
plus a “Tags” section where you can choose
descriptive keywords. For product campaigns, you’ll
also fill out a product stage field.
With all those limited character fields, I learned
pretty quickly that finding the right keywords to tell
your story in a short amount of space is an art. The
blurb needs to be punchy, clear, and attention
grabbing; the project title should succinctly describe
what you’re doing. The project image is also crucial.
It’s so important to use a very clear and representative
image of the project. When people see campaigns on
the site, they are just a bunch of small boxes—you
need to catch their eyes immediately and compel
them to click the project to see your page. (We’ll go
over how to optimize your project page in chapter 4.)
Now for the logistical stuff. On Kickstarter, if you’re
not already signed up, you’ll build a short creator
profile. For Sex and Broadcasting, as the creator of the
campaign, Tim handled this part, entering his profile
photo, name, bio, location, and website(s), and
connecting with Facebook. (You can now set up
Google Analytics, too, which is a tool that follows and
reports your online traffic.)
Both platforms require that creators set up an
account. As usual, this includes contact info. You’ll
need to verify your identity, and you will need to
supply the bank account information for the account
that will be receiving funds, account holder name, and
so on. (On Indiegogo, you will add the bank account
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
information when the first contributor makes a
donation.)
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SETTING UP THE CAMPAIGN PAGE
Because I had worked as a journalist and grant writer,
I knew how to put together strong copy to get
people’s attention (and hopefully get us money). Tim
was the artist—he made a wonderful video. He went
through several iterations until he got one that we
both loved, clocking in at 3 minutes and 27 seconds.
He also knew the WFMU community really well, so he
was able to add touches to what I wrote to make it
resonate with our audience. We made a good team.
When you’re launching a campaign with a partner or
group of people, it’s great to divvy up the roles like
this.
We sent a working draft of the campaign story to a
few trusted colleagues and friends for feedback. Then
we fact-checked and spell-checked the page, before
adding it to Kickstarter.
At one point during our prep work, Tim turned to me
and said, “We probably should make a press release,
huh?”
“Definitely!” I said, and then I quickly Googled how
to write one. You can tell I was really just making it up
as I went along with this first campaign.
And, we still needed to come up with a key
component of our campaign: rewards.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
CREATING REWARDS
Tim and I reached out to Ken at WFMU, and he told us
the station had shot glasses, t-shirts, and other kinds
of WFMU swag he could donate to the campaign. Tim
also contacted record labels, and we received some
great LPs and DVDs—some that were even signed by
the bands, like a Shins Wincing the Night Away CD
that we offered for a $125 pledge. We had a
connection to the owner of DFA Records, and they
gave us our limited edition offer: vinyl and CDs of LCD
Soundsystem and other one-of-a-kind recordings
made at DFA. Many people in the music industry were
familiar with and supportive of WFMU, so it was
encouraging to see them rally behind us, even before
we launched. (Later we followed up with some of
these contacts and asked them to tweet about and
share the campaign.) Kickstarter now prohibits
projects from offering things that already exist as
rewards, so these packages wouldn’t be accepted
today. But our experience shows the importance of
getting partners and supporters involved in creative
ways.
Tim also came up with a rad reward idea: to let
backers add their very own “subliminal message” into
the film. They would send a high-definition frame of
their own creation, which would be edited into the
film.
“This is your chance to both support and subvert
the film about the station that subverts THE MAN,”
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
we wrote on the campaign page. We weren’t
completely sure what we were doing, but we were
having fun, and we knew limited edition rewards
would motivate music fans.
Tim estimated the cost to ship the rewards by
getting packaging from USPS and weighing each item
in its package, then calculating the shipping cost by
multiplying the final weights by the number of each
reward we’d have to ship if they got sold out. Once he
knew how much shipping the rewards would cost, he
added the Kickstarter fees, the amount he knew he
needed to edit the film, and 10 percent of wiggle
room—in case there were any unforeseen issues—to
arrive at the final fundraising goal: $50,000.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SUBMITTING OUR CAMPAIGN
Once all the content was finally in the campaign page,
and we reviewed it again and again, we submitted it
to Kickstarter. Kickstarter says it should not take more
than three business days for approval but allow for
some additional time just in case your project has any
issues and you need to make corrections before re-
submitting it. Once your project is approved, you can
launch whenever you want.
Heads up: There are some things you cannot
change after launching on Kickstarter. These include
important public details like your profile name, your
funding goal, the campaign duration, information in the
account tab (except you can change the payment
method when you’re backing another person’s
project), and any reward—with its respective shipping
price—that a backer has pledged for (although you can
modify the quantity of the reward, if it’s limited, and
add more shipping locations). After launching on
Indiegogo, you can’t change publicly known details
like your campaign goal amount, your campaign’s
funding type (fixed or flexible funding); any perks that
have been claimed by a contributor, or your
campaign’s currency. You also cannot change internal
information like the PayPal account listed on your
campaign, and based on your project, the nonprofit
status of your campaign, the nonprofit organization to
which the funds are being sent, some of the U.S. bank
account details, or the tax ID information of where
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
funding is going. Things of course change over time,
so be sure to review the website of the platform you
choose to use before launching.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
LAUNCH DAY
On Launch Day for Sex and Broadcasting, I was up
early and had barely slept. WFMU planned to send out
a newsletter letting all their listeners know about the
campaign that morning, so we needed to make sure
the campaign was live before the newsletter went
out. I called Tim. Over the phone, we both scanned
the campaign page, just making sure everything
looked good.
“Ready?” He asked.
“Ready,” I said. We pressed go, and we were live.
We had no idea what to expect, but pretty quickly
we realized that now that the campaign was
underway, the real work was just beginning. We
couldn’t simply push “Go” on Kickstarter and let the
campaign sit there. It was time to get eyes on that
page and get pledges coming in.
We called Ken to let him know we were live, and
WFMU sent out their newsletter telling subscribers
about the Kickstarter campaign. They also tweeted to
their 80,000-plus followers.
Tim did something brilliant right away that has since
become a standard for me in all my campaigns: in
advance of going live, he asked friends and family in
his network to pledge on the first day. So the morning
that we launched, Tim’s family and friends pledged
immediately, racking up a nice chunk of change on the
page. (By your second or third crowdfunding
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
campaign, you might need to tap into a new audience
to lock in early funds on Day 1. I talk about fundraising
fatigue in chapter 6.) Everyone who visited the page
could see that money was coming in and that the
campaign had traction. It got people excited and ready
to rally behind us. I’ve since come to swear by the
importance of that Launch Day momentum. Now,
with my clients, we always aim to secure 20 percent
of our funding goal very early on.
The first day of the campaign could not have gone
better. Tim’s network, and especially the WFMU
newsletter, gave us a huge push. We raised about
$20,000 of our $50,000 goal. We were off to an
incredible start.
Over the next few days, I spent my mornings, lunch
breaks, evenings, and every spare moment emailing
everyone and their mothers and promoting the project
online. Tim and I cold-emailed press outlets we
thought would be interested in the campaign,
especially local ones in New York, New Jersey, and in
the music industry. Just from this emailing and our
DIY press release, we landed a radio show and the
popular blog BrooklynVegan covered us.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Getting Featured by Kickstarter
At the time of the Sex and Broadcasting
campaign, I had no idea that Kickstarter staff
spends hours looking at projects on their site and
regularly identifying some of them as “Projects
We Love” (adding an official badge to your
campaign page). These campaigns can then
potentially be featured as “Project of the Day” on
each of the category pages, on the homepage
across all categories as “Project of the Day,” or
be picked for the highly coveted homepage
carousel. The platform chooses certain projects to
share on social media, or in the newsletter, too.
There’s never a guarantee that Kickstarter will
feature your project, and there’s no magic
formula. Kickstarter shares its recommendations
for how to build an exceptional project on the site
(such as by writing a great blurb, using lots of
high-quality media and not covering your project
image with banners or badges). In my experience,
here are elements that also help make a project
special enough to be featured.
• Excellent design. When a project looks
professional and beautiful, it goes a
long way. From your logo to your video
to the graphics on your page, artful
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
design can really help a project stand
out.
• Originality. Even if it’s a type of project
that’s been done so many times before
(like a documentary film), there’s an
angle to the story that’s unique and
special.
• Creative impact. I find that Kickstarter
appreciates campaigns that do
something positive for the creative
community—like a project kickstarting
an out-of-print, high-design art book into
the modern world (more on that soon).
• Heart. Personally, I think projects with a
lot of passion and heart have a chance
to do well on the platform. The WFMU
documentary is a great example of that.
The quirky, underfunded radio station
was up against steep odds, and the
campaign told its story in a genuine,
emotional way that made us want to
root for it.
In addition to getting “noticed” by Kickstarter
staff, your project can also benefit from
Kickstarter algorithms that track the community’s
response to campaigns through pledges and
comments, among other factors. Campaigns with
a high level of engagement can get filtered into
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Kickstarter’s “What’s Popular” module. Another
feature, “New & Noteworthy,” is a mix of
recently launched “Projects We Love”
campaigns.
By Day 3, we were halfway to our goal. We had
been named a “Project We Love” by Kickstarter (back
then called a “Staff Pick”), we got an uptick of likes on
Facebook, and, a few days later, we were featured on
USATODAY.com.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Getting Featured by Indiegogo
Likewise, over at Indiegogo, projects can be
featured on the homepage, explore page,
category pages, in collections, on the blog, in the
newsletter, and on social media. Similar to
Kickstarter, Indiegogo has some editorial
discretion over what it features. The platform also
offers recommendations about how to prepare
your campaign for success, including tips like
creating professional-quality graphics, making a
great pitch video, having a social media strategy,
and others.
If you want to get featured by Indiegogo, the
big thing to keep in mind is what the platform
calls the “gogofactor.” Indiegogo COO/Founder
Danae Ringelmann says, “We believe in an even
playing field where everyone has equal
opportunity for success. We feature and promote
campaigns based on their gogofactor.”
The gogofactor is an algorithm that helps
campaigns get greater visibility on Indiegogo. It’s
influenced by factors like social engagement and
global reach. To help boost your gogofactor,
Indiegogo provides these tips (and as you
continue reading this book, you’ll see I definitely
agree with these—and I share my strategies for
each).
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
• Share your campaign link and
encourage your community to share to
drive traffic to your campaign.
• Post updates about your campaign and
spread the word through social media.
• Be sure to offer perks that would
engage your audience and help
encourage them to contribute.
Don’t worry. You will learn how to do this through
this book!
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
KEEPING UP MOMENTUM
In the second week of our campaign, pledging slowed
to a complete crawl. There were a few days when
only a handful of pledges came in. Tim and I were
completely freaked out. Were we going to make it?
Since then, I’ve learned that the mid-campaign
slump is pretty natural in crowdfunding, and it’s just
about unavoidable. For most campaigns, pledges will
come in strongly at the beginning and end, but they
will be weaker in the middle (read more about this in
chapter 6).
Tim and I kept plugging away, staying active on
social media and pitching new press outlets. As the
campaign progressed, Tim also released updates to
backers through Kickstarter. Instead of writing generic
messages, like “We’re doing great! Keep spreading
the word!” Tim shared new, fun, useful content, like
videos where he’d update backers about rewards and
press coverage, and exclusive videos from the WFMU
archives. This became another strategy I’ve since
taken to other campaigns: planning interesting content
to share with backers throughout the campaign is
really valuable. It’s how you show your sincere
appreciation, form a community (that’s what
crowdfunding is all about), and keep people interested
in the campaign. Releasing new rewards during the
campaign is also a great way to generate new interest
and attention.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
We reached our $50,000 goal with 12 days left to
go. But we didn’t let up—by the end of the 30-day
campaign, we raised 163 percent of our goal, raising
$81,639 from 736 backers due to a ton of on-the-fly
learning, hard work, and a passionate group of people
who wanted to keep a beloved freeform radio station
alive. And a dose of beginner’s luck didn’t hurt!
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
THE POWER OF A BUILT-IN AUDIENCE
My first crowdfunding campaign was a lot of things: a
hot mess, a rush, a learning experience, a lot of
stress, and a lot of fun. I still had so much to learn
about crowdfunding. But already the wheels were
turning. I’d learned about the rhythm of a campaign
and how much work actually went into networking,
updating, pitching, and engaging our audience on a
daily basis. I saw how our rewards were perfect for
the community we were reaching out to. I saw how
Tim’s awesome trailer got people talking. I saw the
value of getting an influx of pledges on Launch Day,
the powerful effect of Kickstarter’s support, and the
momentum that press coverage brought.
Looking back at the Sex and Broadcasting
campaign, it’s clear that although our preparation and
hard work paid off, what influenced its success the
most was its following. Without the WFMU listeners, I
don’t know if we could have made it to the finish line.
The number one thing I learned in my first
crowdfunding campaign is the power of the fan base
—the built-in audience.
A built-in audience is the most motivated,
enthusiastic segment of your “crowd.” They are the
people who make your project a success. They are the
people who are inherently interested in you or your
project in some way. You want devout interest. The
strength of that built-in audience depends on how
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
devout they are. A built-in audience consists of:
• Engaged subscribers to your mailing list
• Dedicated followers on social media
• Avid readers of your blog
• Loyal listeners of your podcast
• Interested fans in the industry
To engage your built-in audience, you need to make
them aware of and connected to your campaign. You
need a strategy for tapping into and engaging them.
You need a mailing list, active social media accounts,
and a site that people go to. You need to be able to
get the word out in multiple ways. You might have an
amazing project and campaign page, but if no one
sees it, it might as well not exist.
You also need to make sure your built-in audience is
willing and able to pledge money. I learned the hard
way (as you’ll read in chapter 6) that avid social media
followers don’t equal dollars. If your audience is really
young, they may not have money to give you. If
they’re much older, they might not know much about
crowdfunding or be able to donate money online. It’s
important to consider your community’s ability to
pledge before you launch.
Something I also do is compare the campaign to
others. I ask myself: Have there been other
campaigns like this? How did they do? I’m looking to
see what got similar audiences engaged and excited.
Because Sex and Broadcasting was about WFMU, it
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
naturally had a built-in group of WFMU fans who were
excited about a movie being made about their favorite
radio station. WFMU was founded in 1958, so it had
been around for a long time and it had diehard fans.
These fans are the people who made the campaign a
success.
But not every movie will have a built-in audience
who will rally around a crowdfunding campaign. Not
every product will have a willing list of backers just
waiting to spend money on it. It’s important to assess
if a fan base is really a dedicated bunch. That’s
essential, and it’s something I do now before every
single campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WHAT IF I DON’T HAVE A BUILT-IN AUDIENCE?
This is a question I hear a lot from clients. I always tell
them the same thing: It’s imperative to invest months
(if not years!) into growing your relationship with the
people in your audience. Failing to find a crowd is one
of the biggest things that trip up creators. It can be
hard to be patient and focus on this aspect of the
campaign when you have a great idea and you want to
move quickly—I know. But it’s one of the most critical
aspects of the process.
There are seven main tactics I use to help clients
find, evaluate, and connect with their built-in
audiences, and you’ll see them in action throughout
the rest of this book. Here they are:
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
1. START COLLECTING EMAIL ADDRESSES.
The call-to-action on your website (or just a landing
page to start) should be for people to sign up for your
mailing list. Incentivize visitors to the site to sign up by
ensuring they will be the first to know when your
campaign goes live, so they can be the first to access
early-bird pricing, or offering something in return, like a
giveaway (a digital asset or a raffle where a new
subscriber could receive a prize). The goal is to build
up the biggest mailing list you can. Later, not only will
you be able to reach these people by email, but you’ll
also be able to use the email addresses in digital
marketing efforts, such as social media advertising
(more in chapter 7).
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
2. GET SOCIAL.
If you don’t have social media accounts, open them.
Ask your friends to follow you and to help spread the
word. Follow like-minded accounts that are relevant to
your project, and engage in conversations. Be
strategic about developing a brand voice and sharing
great content. We’ll cover this in more detail in
chapter 7.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
3. DO YOUR RESEARCH.
Identify people, blogs, reporters, and influencers who
are already talking about topics related to your project.
Follow and study them. Eventually, you’ll want to rally
as many influential people around your project as you
can.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
4. INVEST IN DIGITAL MARKETING.
Leading up to your campaign, you can use digital
marketing, like social media advertising, to drive
people to your website or landing page where you can
capture email addresses and build your audience.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
5. PERSONALIZE YOUR MESSAGES.
When it comes time to invite others to support your
project, show journalists and influencers that you did
your research. Send screenshots of their tweets or
mention specific stories they wrote that connect to
your mission. Let them know you know what you’re
talking about, and that your project directly relates to
their interests.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
6. PRIORITIZE GREAT DESIGN.
While you are doing all the above, invest in hiring a
designer early on to create a strong brand identity (and
if your campaign is for a product, the product design).
You will base your social media, campaign page,
messaging, and video off this necessary design work.
It’s how you’ll establish a professional visual brand
identity that commands attention. We talk about this
in chapters 2, 4, and 5.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
7. BE YOUR BIGGEST CHEERLEADER.
You love this project. This is your baby! Make sure
that everyone knows that you love it, and why they
should love it too. When you show how devoted you
are to your project, people connect with that.
Looking back—after having successfully managed
over fifty crowdfunding campaigns—I feel incredibly
fortunate that my first ever campaign was for Sex and
Broadcasting, a film that was so perfect for
crowdfunding and one that is close to my heart.
As Ken later told the publication Passive/Aggressive
about funding Sex and Broadcasting, “The hardest
part is finding a way to support such an effort
financially, without selling out the mission. I think
crowdfunding is the best financial model for it. If too
much control is given to one entity such as the
government, or a university, or even a wealthy
individual, then the agenda for the organization will be
set by that one entity. Crowdfunding spreads the
funding out among many people, which is the best
way to go.”
As for me? The experience completely changed the
way I thought about fundraising for the movies I was
working on.
I was hooked.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Chapter 2
Making a Killer Campaign Video
In 2014, almost two years after my first crowdfunding
campaign, I was hired to help Neil Young with his new
audio initiative, Pono. Neil and the Pono team had
created an audio player called the PonoPlayer, which
was designed to play the highest resolution digital
music possible, and they were going to launch it on
Kickstarter.
Since running the Sex and Broadcasting campaign,
I’d run six more crowdfunding campaigns, mostly for
other documentary projects. They’d all been
successful, but I was still working from my kitchen
table in my apartment and trying to figure out where
my patchwork career was heading. I didn’t know
anyone else doing this kind of work, and I barely knew
what to call my campaign management job. Now,
suddenly, my client was Neil (bleeping) Young! On top
of that, up to this point, the highest amount I had
raised for a campaign was just over $80,000 (on my
very first campaign). The goal for the Pono campaign
was $800,000.
With just over a week to make the campaign a slam
dunk, I got to work. I got up to speed on the
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PonoPlayer. I reviewed the campaign page materials
created by the Pono team and offered feedback,
working through numerous drafts with the whole
team—despite my lack of knowledge about high
resolution audio. We talked about their outreach plan,
and I reviewed the press release and got the details
on the plan for the South by Southwest festival
(SXSW), where Neil himself would be announcing the
campaign at a big keynote.
Everything was very quickly coming together. But
there was still one big question mark: just days before
launch, I still hadn’t seen the video. The video is a
critical component of any crowdfunding campaign, but
for this one, it felt especially important because we
had to use it to overcome an obstacle: backers
wouldn’t be able to experience the PonoPlayer’s epic
sound quality without actually using one, so we
needed to find a way to communicate what the sound
was like without actually being able to provide it. Fans
trust Neil Young, so we had a leg up. But the video
was still going to be key to the campaign.
I asked about the video’s status, eager to see it, and
was told it was over 10 minutes long. I was floored. A
10-plus-minute Kickstarter video? It was unheard of.
We can’t do that! I thought. Everything I’d learned up
to this point indicated that attention spans are short,
so videos always had to be. Not to mention, people I
spoke to in the crowdfunding industry had confirmed
this, too. But by the time I heard about the video’s
length, there wasn’t enough time to change it.
Right before we launched, I finally got to see it. At
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
11 minutes and 24 seconds, the video starts off with
back-to-back clips of the world’s top musicians
providing powerful testimonials about how impressed
they are with the PonoPlayer. There’s Norah Jones,
Beck, David Crosby, Arcade Fire, Tom Petty, Anthony
Kiedis, Elvis Costello, Reggie Watts, Eddie Vedder,
and others. The video cuts from one incredible
musician to the next, all talking about how much they
love the PonoPlayer. As you watch, you’re on the
edge of your seat, and the sheer number of rock stars
raving about this player makes the video utterly
convincing.
The 11 minutes went by in a flash, and the video
was perfect. Wow, I thought. This changes things. I
was fascinated.
Then the project launched, and for 35 days I
managed the campaign. We ended up raising a
whopping $6.2 million—the third most funded
Kickstarter campaign ever at the time.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WE’RE STORYTELLING MACHINES
The Pono project reinforced just how critical a
powerful campaign video could be, but it also made
me realize that not only can it be okay to break the
rules of crowdfunding—sometimes you absolutely
have to. Each campaign requires a nuanced, tailored
approach to how you communicate with backers, from
the video to the campaign page and beyond. So while
I hope my experiences and advice here are useful to
you, remember, it’s not set in stone. Creativity and the
freedom to communicate in a way that makes sense
for your project is just as important. Sometimes, that
means an 11-minute video.
From my perspective, part of what compels backers
to give is believing in something. It’s not about
investing in a product as an exchange of money for
goods; it’s about seeing and hearing a story that
resonates.
At our core, humans are storytelling machines. We
connect best to an idea when it has a narrative. It’s
the same reason movies have such emotional power
—when we go see a film, our own feelings, stories,
and memories come to life before our eyes. In
crowdfunding, the campaign video presents a huge
opportunity for creators to harness the power of
storytelling to connect with backers. When your
campaign message reaches backers on a personal,
intimate, individual basis, that’s when it can inspire
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
them to take action.
This lesson isn’t just valuable for crowdfunders: it’s
critical for anyone trying to build a brand, promote
their idea or project, connect with new audiences, and
captivate people online. In other words, you always
need to tell a great story.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PRESSING PLAY
Some of my favorite campaign videos of ours have
been the ones that felt the least like fundraising
videos.
And as I learned with the PonoPlayer, there’s no
standard length or style or formula that equals
success. Each project will be different, but you can
follow best practices. Here are seven things you
should keep in mind.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
1. USE THE RIGHT TOOLS—AND/OR HIRE A PROFESSIONAL.
Please don’t sit in front of your laptop camera and
shoot a video of yourself explaining why people
should give money to your project. It’s tempting, I
know—and so cheap. But don’t do it! I find that
potential donors will assume that if your video is low
quality, your product will probably be low quality too.
Show the world that you put care and time into the
work you do. Rent the right equipment, or even
better, hire a professional—because, let’s be real, you
might not even know how to use that equipment by
yourself. If you have no cash up front, try to get
creative. Do a trade with a filmmaker friend. You
might be able to work out a deal where you can pay
them upon success of the campaign.
In a post I wrote for CNBC, Hamish Smyth—our
design director and my frequent collaborator—nailed
the importance of a well-produced video when he
said, “It is no longer good enough to skimp on
production and put something out there half-baked. If
it’s worth doing, it’s worth doing right.”
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
2. KEEP IT SHORT.
Neil Young produced a killer 11-minute campaign
video. It worked because he demonstrated the power
of an audio product that backers couldn’t hear through
a group of experts who conveyed it for him. Chances
are, though, you won’t need 11 minutes to tell your
story.
In general, I recommend keeping your video length
to under 4 minutes. If you communicate the most
important information about your project within that
period of time, potential backers can likely make an
informed decision. After that, you can use your project
page to further explain any details or technical aspects
about your project or product—in another video, in
text, and/or in visual form. Especially if you have a
complicated product design, or if there are a lot of
technical details, aim to focus the video on the top
few things you want backers to know, and then
expand on the rest in the page.
In 2016, we used a unique video approach when we
worked with Anicorn Watches on a campaign to fund
their awesome battery-free Anicorn Series K452
Watches. Because the Anicorn Series K452 was all
about space-inspired mechanics and design, the team
produced an unconventional 90-second video
combining images of space with images of the
watches. The video, which featured up-close shots of
the watches as if they’re floating like satellites, had no
voiceover or interview with the creators. It was pretty
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
abstract, but also super cool, and it fit perfectly with
their brand and product. Still, we needed to tell a
story. To accomplish that, we added a second 5-
minute video at the top of the project page where the
two founders explained their connection, their project,
and their passion for their watch. Boom. The
campaign went on to reach the goal within the first 24
hours. This kind of two-video approach can work for
certain projects, particularly if you have the budget and
resources, and it makes sense for the brand.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
3. GET FEEDBACK.
Pono wasn’t the only campaign where I broke my 4-
minute rule. In 2014, we did a Kickstarter for a
documentary about Joan Didion (read the full story in
chapter 8). The video was on the longer side—just shy
of 6 minutes—but I road tested it by sending it to
friends and colleagues for feedback. When almost
everyone responded saying they watched it to the end
without tuning out, I knew it was a good sign the
video would work.
Don’t cut your video off mid-story because you’re
trying to keep it short. Use your best judgment and
share various cuts of the video with all kinds of people
who can provide valuable feedback throughout the
pre-launch process.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
4. GET TO THE POINT!
One of the most important pieces of advice I give to
clients about their videos is to get to the most
essential point of your project within the first 30
seconds. Otherwise, backers can lose interest. Be
punchy, direct, and clear, right off the bat. Even
though you love this project and you could ramble on
about it forever, strangers may not feel the same way,
and you have to draw in as many as you can right
away.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
5. TELL A STORY (THAT ALSO GIVES VIEWERS ALL THE
NECESSARY INFORMATION).
People want to be a part of your project. They want to
feel a connection to it on a deeper level than if they
were just shopping at a department store. This is one
of the really special things about crowdfunding!
Backers want to donate to a person with intention and
motivation—someone who has a story. In your video,
create a story that shows how your experience is a
journey and invite backers along for the ride.
Campaign videos should typically address these
core questions.
• How did the project come about?
• What is it?
• What does or will the idea/product do? What
problem does it solve?
• Where is it in development right now?
• Why are you crowdfunding?
• Where is the money going?
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
6. WRITE A SCRIPT AND MAKE A STORYBOARD.
Create a list of the essential points you need to nail in
the video, and then write a script. The script will
include the key talking points for the video and an idea
of who will say them (you, your partner creator, or
someone else you’re interviewing for the video).
Remember to create a narrative: there should be a
beginning, a middle, and an end. Then create a
storyboard by adding what you plan to show on the
screen to correspond with each part of the script.
When we were concepting the video for our
awesome client Makerarm, a digital fabrication system
that does 3D printing and much more, we knew the
opening line of our script would introduce the product.
We wanted the product to have a voice, which we’d
achieve with a voiceover, and our first line was “Hello,
I am Makerarm! The world’s first multifunctional
robotic unit that fits anywhere in your workspace.”
Along with the script, we created a storyboard with
the shots we wanted to go along with each
statement. Before production, we practiced reading
the final script to make sure it sounded natural when
spoken. We also sent it around to trusted friends and
colleagues for their feedback on whether any areas
didn’t make sense or were unnecessary. And we
collaborated with our film team, too, to be certain
about what would work visually, and what might not.
Making a script and storyboard means that when
you go to shoot and produce your video, you’re likely
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
to be much more efficient with your time and costly
resources. You’ll probably end up revising your
storyboard after you shoot your interview(s), and
that’s okay. The exercise is valuable for distilling your
message, staying focused, and optimizing your time.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
7. BE YOURSELF.
People are not just buying into your project, but you
too. It’s key to show your genuine, authentic,
passionate self in your video in order to establish a
connection with potential backers. So be you! If you’re
raising money for an online comedy series, for
example, make your video funny so that backers can
experience your sense of humor. If you go against
who you are or what your project is trying to be, it
won’t work.
Of course, some of us are camera shy, and it can
feel like a lot of pressure to get in front of a camera
and share our projects. For our campaign to raise
funds for the documentary Art and Craft, which
follows one of the most prolific art forgers in U.S.
history, the filmmakers were uncomfortable talking on
camera. They were filmmakers, not actors, and being
in front of the camera made them squirm—mostly
when it came to “the ask” for support of their project.
So they got creative—and had a little fun. They
introduced themselves with a quick clip in the
introduction and then asked their siblings to narrate
the video. One is an actress, the other is a theater
director, so they were a bit less camera shy! It worked
out really well, and the video was a big success. So
was the campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
DON’T JUST TAKE MY WORD FOR IT
In the early days of Vann Alexandra, when we were
still working in a coworking office space in Brooklyn,
my team and I sublet desks from a husband-and-wife
filmmaking team called RAVA Films (a combination of
their names, Rafael and Ava). They make stunning
documentaries and films for leading arts organizations
such as the Peabody Award–winning Art21 and other
big corporations like Sprint and Pepsi. I got to
experience their talent for myself when we hired them
to create the Kickstarter video for the Joan Didion
documentary campaign. Since then, I’ve partnered
with them on some hugely successful crowdfunding
projects, and I am always blown away and inspired by
their work. So I asked them for their thoughts on
making a successful crowdfunding video.
First, we talked about some of the challenges. You
can probably guess one of the hardest things about
making a crowdfunding video: fitting it all in! You have
to take something that’s complex and has a lot of
parts and boil it down to a video that’s short, powerful,
and has a strong message. (That’s why it’s so
important to write out a script and get feedback on it.)
RAVA also pointed out that while the call-to-action
of the campaign is to get pledges, that shouldn’t be
the focus of the film. Instead, strive to make the story
itself as strong as possible because that’s what will
make viewers want to pledge—not asking them to.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
When they worked with us on the Joan Didion
campaign, for instance, the Kickstarter video ended up
being a micro biopic about Joan Didion’s life as a
writer, mother, and wife.
Another consideration when making a crowdfunding
video is what it says about you and your brand. The
video introduces you and your campaign to a new
audience. It’s a lot different from traditional
advertising, where you’re usually talking to a seasoned
audience. (Think about how many times you’ve seen a
Coke ad, for example.) With crowdfunding, you’re
typically initiating a new relationship with a new
audience. “That’s why you have to think so much
about how you’re building an identity,” RAVA says.
“You’re not just making a video, you’re creating a
brand image around the project. The video, and the
whole campaign, is an exercise in branding.” (We will
go deeper into this in chapter 4.)
This might seem obvious, but RAVA says to avoid
closely mimicking other campaigns. “Sometimes
people think there’s a magic formula and if you
replicate the same video or the same idea that worked
for another campaign, then you also will succeed,”
RAVA points out. But every company or project has to
find its own language and messaging.
When it comes to actually making the video, RAVA
too suggests trying to achieve as much production
quality as possible. If you have a limited budget, a DIY
video is an option, but not everyone can pull it off. Try
to find people in your network who have professional
experience in video production, and focus on quality
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
editing. If you end up shooting the video yourself,
having it professionally edited can help make sure the
story comes together effectively.
TAKE IT FROM RAVA.
• Again, get feedback. Something you might
think is important might not be important to
the outside world, and vice versa.
• Don’t read off a script. You will sound like a
robot.
• Making the ask should be the shortest part
of your video. Keep most of the focus on
the story.
• Transcribe. After you shoot your interview
footage, transcribe what was said and read
it. This makes it easier to identify what to
include and what to cut. This is where your
professional editor comes in!
• Use music to heighten or enhance sections
of the piece. Videos with only one piece of
continuous music in the background often
don’t have any momentum.
• Don’t use unlicensed music. Hire a
composer or use royalty-free music. Finding
the right music can take days or weeks, so
make sure you allot time to do it.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full: Chapter 3
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
How to Get an Old Design Book
to Go Viral
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PART I: THE SUBWAY MANUAL EDITION
In 2012, Hamish Smyth and Jesse Reed, two New
York–based designers, made an unexpected discovery
in the basement of their office building. Dust and piles
of junk had accumulated over the eighteen years since
Pentagram moved into the building. It was under a pile
of dirty gym clothes that they found something
incredible: an original 1970 New York City Transit
Authority (NYCTA) Graphics Standards Manual—a big
red binder that contains every design element and
instruction for implementation of the signage of the
New York City Subway.
Created by the visionary designers Massimo Vignelli
and Bob Noorda of Unimark, the NYCTA Graphics
Standards Manual has become legendary in the
design community and beyond. Jesse remembered
studying the manual in undergrad, even redesigning it
as part of his thesis. Its pages include specifications
for how colors, shapes, and fonts should be used in
subway signage. It’s a working document that has
informed the way people get around New York City
for decades, and it has grown in stature to be
considered a work of art. Hamish later described the
discovery: “For graphic designers, finding the Manual
was equivalent to finding the Rosetta Stone.”
Hamish and Jesse flipped through the pages the
rest of the afternoon, mesmerized, then began to
hatch an idea: What if they could share this with their
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
friends? They photographed each page and put the
whole thing online at www.standardsmanual.com and
sent it around to a few friends and colleagues who
they figured would love to nerd out like they had. (The
site has since been updated—more on that later.)
They completely underestimated how many people
would be into it. Within a few days, the site had
250,000 views. They later got some press, too—a
couple of articles and some interviews. “This would
make a great book,” they thought. But how would
they make it? And what about the copyright? The
excitement died down, other things took their
attention away from the manual, and that big red
binder sat on a shelf waiting.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
A VIRAL SUCCESS
Hamish and I met at a party in the spring of 2014, just
a week after the Neil Young PonoPlayer campaign
wrapped and a couple of years after the discovery of
the manual. I’d helped the Pono team raise over $6.2
million, and I had finally embraced being the
“Crowdsourceress” and started pursuing it as my
career.
At one point, everyone gathered together for a
toast. Hamish and I had never spoken to each other
before, but he locked eyes with me as we clinked
glasses and said, “Are you ready?” That was all it
took. We started talking and immediately hit it off.
We’ve been collaborating (and dating) ever since.
(You’ll hear about our work together in several places
throughout this book.)
Not long after we met, Hamish told me the story of
how he found the NYCTA Graphics Standards Manual
(what we simply called the “Standards Manual” or the
“NYCTA manual”). He was still giddy about finding it,
even though it was some two years later. I thought it
was really cool, but as I wasn’t a designer—I didn’t
fully understand the freak-out factor of this geeky
piece of history. And of course I had no idea that this
binder would lead to one of my most successful
crowdfunding projects to date.
But then Hamish told me what happened when he
and Jesse photographed it and put it online.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
“Did you say a quarter of a million people checked
out the site? In just a few days? For a book about
subway signs?” I asked.
He nodded.
“We also got press in Gizmodo and Under
Consideration, and a bunch of people were tweeting
about it,” he told me.
Then my brain clicked into gear. “Have you ever
thought about doing a Kickstarter?”
Once I heard about what a viral success the website
had been, I immediately saw huge potential in the
manual. This binder full of fonts and colors had
something that could propel it to crowdfunding
success: a built-in audience. In the same way WFMU
fans had so eagerly supported Tim’s Sex and
Broadcasting documentary, an enthusiastic
community of designers would rally around this
project.
Before I got too pumped up about taking the manual
to Kickstarter, Hamish pointed out an issue that could
potentially stop us in our tracks: The copyright was
retained by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority
(MTA). Hamish thought it all seemed too hard to pull
off, plus he and Jesse had demanding full-time jobs at
Pentagram.
But I was determined. “How can we get this in
front of the MTA?” I asked.
“Well come to think of it, MTA is now a Pentagram
client,” he said.
“Then could you just ask the MTA about reissuing
the manual?”
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
He did. And after a few meetings, the MTA gave us
the okay and prepared an agreement. I have a feeling
they had the exact same reaction I did when I first
talked to Hamish about the manual. Is anyone really
interested in an out-of-print binder about subway
signage?
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
BUILDING THE BOOK
With approval from the MTA, there was nothing
stopping us: Jesse, Hamish, and I began preparing a
Kickstarter campaign to crowdfund a reissue of the
Standards Manual.
Our goal was to reissue the Standards Manual as a
full-size, high-quality hardcover book. Knowing our
audience would likely be mostly designers, we
recognized that one of our biggest strengths would be
the book itself. We set out to make sure the
reproduced version of the manual would be visually
stunning—a collector’s item that our audience would
find incredible.
In addition to ensuring the book itself was beautiful
and well made, as part of the reissue, we wanted to
add a foreword and essay to set the tone of the book
and add to its appeal. One of Jesse’s contacts
recommended New York magazine writer Christopher
Bonanos as someone knowledgeable and passionate
about NYC, transit, and design. When Hamish and
Jesse brought the idea to Chris, he said, “I was meant
to write this.” We hired Chris to write a 6,000-plus-
word essay on the history of the Standards Manual,
which included interviewing people who worked on
the successors to the Standards Manual and MTA
staff—all original insider knowledge our designer
audience would be excited to get their hands on.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
In Conversation with Hamish Smyth: Designing and
Budgeting for the NYCTA Graphics Standards Manual
Reissue
Hamish, being a designer himself, had a ton of
knowledge about the nuts and bolts of creating
this beautiful package. I spoke to him about the
process.
Dreaming Up the Book
The size of the sheets in the original Standards
Manual binder was 13" by 13" and we wanted to
maintain that size. From our experience designing
and producing book and print projects at
Pentagram, we thought a four-color job would do
the trick. We also wanted our book to have a
cloth cover, and be all around high quality. Those
were our starting points.
Finding a Printer
We talked to about fifteen printers before
choosing an Italian printer who specialized in high-
quality art books who could bind the size book we
wanted to make.
Designing the Book and Considering Costs
Based on conversations with friends in the
industry, Jesse and I figured that if you found a
book like this in the bookstore, you might pay up
to $150 for it, but on Kickstarter, we thought
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
people wouldn’t want to pay more than about
$100. This was our first time doing a project like
this, so we didn’t have a track record with
potential backers. Plus, backers wouldn’t be able
to see and feel the quality of the book as they
would if they were in a store.
We met with a representative from the printer,
and she brought some sample books with her as
well as paper types so we could see what we
could get for our money. We told her what we
liked, and then she followed up by sending us a
detailed estimate with a number of quality and
cost options.
The printer gave us quotes for how much it
would cost to print 500, 1,000, 2,000, and 5,000
books. As the quantity goes up, cost per copy
comes down. They also said they could package
the books in custom cardboard boxes, adding
about 50 cents to the production cost of each
book.
To design the book the way we wanted to, the
cost of producing each unit was coming out at
around $98.
Planning to Ship
The printer sent us a blank dummy copy so we
could make sure we were happy with the weight,
paper, and cover material. We weighed it so we
could start estimating shipping costs. We got
connected to a U.S.-based distribution company
and told them the size and weight of the book,
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
and they gave us an estimate of the costs to ship
to each worldwide destination.
The way Kickstarter is set up now, you can
easily transfer the shipping costs to backers, if
you want, by adding the shipping fees from your
distribution partner to Kickstarter in the back end
before launching, which is tacked on to the
backer’s pledge amount at check out.
Finalizing Costs
Our budget spreadsheet included the following
costs.
• Making the book
• Shipping the book
• Making the video, including original
music we commissioned
• Scanning the manual (Jesse and I
would do the layout)
• Paying the writers of the foreword and
introductory essay
• Fee for campaign management by Vann
Alexandra
• A tiny bit of buffer for unexpected costs
Then we considered taxes and fees, including
an import tax as well as a sea freight fare to get
the books from the Italian printer to the U.S.-
based fulfillment partner. We also factored in
Kickstarter’s payment and processing fees.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Setting and Reaching Our Goal
Producing 1,000 books would bring us to our
$108,000 goal, which would mean we would
barely scrape by. Thankfully, we surpassed our
goal, and as we sold more books and our unit
cost began to decrease, we were able to put the
additional money back into the book. We
introduced eight spot colors and upgraded to
Stochastic printing (to render details more clearly)
and hand-sewn bindings. We shared the
upgrades with the backer community, and
everyone loved it.
Hamish and Jesse approached Pentagram partner
Michael Bierut, their boss, to write the foreword.
Michael is a bona fide graphic design god, and before
joining Pentagram he worked for ten years under
Massimo Vignelli, one of the original creators of the
Standards Manual. (There is an entire generation of
current designers out there who fetishize Vignelli’s
work.) When Hamish and Jesse asked Michael if he
would be in our Kickstarter video, too, he said yes.
Including him in the book and campaign was key.
Hamish and Jesse were intent on finding an
excellent printer for the book, and after some research
and asking around, they found one they liked in Italy.
The pair had hoped to print in the U.S., but because of
the oversized binding of the book (13.5"), they were
unable to find a domestic printer with the hand-binding
capabilities needed. The plan was to scan each page
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
