your fundraising goal, put out feelers to get a sense
for how others react to it. Talk to colleagues or
creators who are familiar with the industry or have
previously crowdfunded in the same category. What’s
their reaction to your funding goal?
You can also check out the competition. How much
have campaigns similar to yours been able to raise in
the past? Can you send customer surveys to a random
pool of individuals who can tell you if the goal seems
too high? Whenever possible, gauge your target
audience’s reaction before you launch.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
DETERMINING REWARDS
In rewards-based crowdfunding, backers are donating
to your project because they believe in it. But of
course, people love getting stuff in return for their
money. Great rewards can drive the success of your
project. Offering something really special can help
someone on the fence decide to pledge. It can make
the difference between someone deciding to pledge
$25 or $75; it can mean a backer is more likely to
share the campaign with friends; and it can even
mean more press attention or the support and
involvement of influencers.
As you brainstorm rewards, first, check what you
can’t offer. Both Kickstarter and Indiegogo have lists
of banned rewards and perks. I advise my clients to
keep these things in mind:
Put your audience first. For any reward you consider,
ask yourself if it’s something you believe your
particular niche audience would get excited about.
Keep it simple. For the NYCTA and NASA Graphics
Standards Manual reissues, our rewards were just the
books themselves. That’s what backers wanted—not
a postcard or a mug, but the book. If your campaign is
straightforward, that’s good! Don’t feel pressure to
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
add tchotchkes that aren’t really connected with your
mission.
Be cognizant of budget. Don’t offer something that is
going to eat up your budget or be a logistical burden.
Incorporate digital rewards that cost nothing to ship.
Understand what is realistic. After you finish your
campaign, you’ll be focused on using the money
you’ve raised to do what you set out to do (e.g., edit
your documentary film). So be careful about time-
consuming experiential rewards. If you’re a director of
a film promising twenty-five one-on-one lunches as
rewards with individual backers, stop and consider if
that’s actually going to be feasible for you.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
When High-Value Rewards Work
How an “off-topic” reward for £5,000 made a big difference
In late 2015, Michael Bierut, Hamish’s past boss
at Pentagram and a world class designer,
introduced me to another incredible Pentagram
partner based in London: Marina Willer. Marina
was working on a short documentary film called
Red Trees about her family’s escape from Nazi
occupation during World War II. Told through the
perspective of her father, who was a child at the
time, the film is beautifully shot and its story
artfully told. Michael put Marina and me in touch
because she was planning to crowdfund the film.
I was honored to help.
The campaign came together really well. The
video was powerful and the page looked great,
with stills from the film, graphics, and behind-the-
scenes photos to support the story. We offered
rewards often seen in film crowdfunding,
including a digital copy of the film, tickets to the
premiere, and an opportunity to Skype with the
director, Marina.
Still, I kept thinking about how we might be
able to use Marina’s design expertise in another
way. She is very well known in the design world
and has been the creative force behind major
identity schemes, including the logo for the Tate
Gallery. What if some backers might be able to
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
use Marina’s design acumen? We came up with
an idea to offer a logo design as a reward,
custom-made by Marina and her Pentagram
team. We limited the reward to two opportunities
and priced them at a considerably discounted fee,
£5,000 (about $8,500) each.
In the update to backers, Marina wrote: “My
work as a graphic designer has always informed
my filmmaking and vice versa. It’s a symbiotic
process. Because of this, it felt right to bring my
life as a graphic designer into the process of
making Red Trees. I wanted to make this reward
an opportunity for people who wouldn’t ordinarily
work with Pentagram to connect with us.”
To strengthen the connection between the
reward and the film, Marina also asked that it be
claimed by a small company or NGO that shared
the film’s values of acceptance and tolerance.
To help spread the word about the special
reward, I suggested Marina and her Pentagram
team reach out to past clients to let them know
about the opportunity. This way, we were
penetrating a design-centric audience. And
because the reward was unique, we also used it
in press pitches.
By thinking just a little outside the box, we
were able to offer something that generated
interest, appealed to the media, and ultimately
attracted backers, too. Both rewards were
claimed, raising £10,000 ($17,000) for the
campaign—around 25 percent of our total goal. In
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
the end, we surpassed our initial target and raised
£42,766 ($72,700). Marina later told me that the
campaign generated so much visibility that a New
York investor came forward and offered to turn
the short film into a feature with worldwide
distribution.
Super-high-value rewards like this don’t always
work, but they can be worth a shot if you can
combine multiple qualities of great rewards. In
this case, we offered a limited number, and the
reward was exclusive to Kickstarter (creating
urgency). It was also a stellar deal (huge
discount!), press worthy, and connected to the
mission of the campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PRICING REWARDS
If you’re using a production partner, refer to their
quotes to understand the exact cost of producing each
item. You will probably want to add a markup to
rewards to safeguard against future issues, such as if
one is damaged in transit and you have to refund or
resend it. After the markup, if the reward seems too
expensive, then rethink it. If a poster is becoming too
expensive to print and ship, for instance, consider a
digital option like a cool image for a backer’s desktop.
Offer a range of prices with your rewards. In
general, these ten price points have worked well for
our campaigns: $5, $15, $25, $50, $75, $100, $250,
$500, and then higher tiers between $1,000 and
$10,000. In my opinion, $1 rewards are too low. If you
want to offer more than the ten-reward range, I would
launch your campaign with less to start and then roll
out new rewards throughout your campaign to drive
pledges.
The $25 incentive is the most popular reward
amount on Kickstarter and Indiegogo, so it’s wise to
offer an appealing reward at that level.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
QUALITIES OF A GREAT REWARD
Some of our most popular rewards were successful
because they intrigued and delighted audiences.
Consider these features when coming up with your
own.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
LIMITED AND EXCLUSIVE
Limited edition incentives can be big hits for all types
of campaigns. Offer a limited edition version of your
product, or offer a reward that is a limited edition.
Limited edition rewards create a sense of urgency.
People realize that they have to act fast when a
product or promotion is limited. This is another reason
why it’s great to have limited early-bird versions of
your product (a limited number at a lower price).
You also elevate the product’s quality and generate
buzz. A limited edition gives a product implied value
due to its quantity. And, if people see that a great
product is limited, they are more likely to tell their
friends to jump on the opportunity as well.
When we crowdfunded the NYCTA Graphics
Standards Manual (see chapter 3), due to our contract
with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the
book was going to be available only during the
campaign. The whole project was an exclusive, one-
time event, and that had backers scrambling to pledge
during the 30 days it was available.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
ORIGINAL
Because the crowdfunding space is so saturated and
competitive, originality is crucial. Spend time on
crowdfunding sites as you prepare your own
campaign, and get familiar with the landscape of
rewards and perks. Start brainstorming about ways in
which you can stand out through rewards.
For the Joan Didion campaign (see chapter 8), we
came up with a digital cookbook of her recipes. Didion
is a writer, yes, but she is also known to be an
excellent cook who has hosted countless dinner
parties. We scanned her original handwritten recipes,
and Hamish, who helped design the digital rewards,
created a beautiful PDF. It was something totally
unique with a great story behind it, and the backers, if
you’ll pardon the pun, ate it up.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
INCLUSIVE
Crowdfunding is all about creating a community. For
product-based campaigns, there’s a great opportunity
to communicate to backers that the product is still at a
stage where backers’ feedback is highly valued.
Honoring this inclusive mentality in the rewards
communicates to campaign supporters that their
voices are being considered.
For the Bellingcat campaign (chapter 5), our most
important reward was providing exclusive access to
the beta version of the site. With the early access, we
wanted to show backers that they were part of the
development process of the website. “We’re a team
and you’re part of it,” we wrote.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
CREATIVE
Whether you are a filmmaker, tech developer, writer,
or dancer, think of rewards as an opportunity to get
creative. Use them to show your personality as a
creator and brand, and connect with backers. Creative
incentives are an easy way to show how prepared and
thoughtful you are about the project and how much
you are investing into it.
For the Sex and Broadcasting documentary (chapter
1), we offered a subliminal message at the $100 level
(backers pledged to have their very own subliminal
message added to the film). Not only was this a
creative reward, but it also appealed to the quirky
audience we were targeting, which made it extra
special.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
DIGITAL
Getting crafty with digital options will save you the
costly and time-consuming process of sorting out
production and shipping. Digital rewards are generally
easier to produce and cost nothing to ship. What we
tend to suggest for digital rewards is to email
everyone who backed a digital reward after the
campaign with a link so they can download the
reward.
That’s the approach we took with a few rewards for
the Joan Didion campaign. One reward, for instance,
was a set of weekly columns that Didion and her
husband, John, wrote for the Saturday Evening Post.
We offered a special collection as a PDF, and after the
campaign, we sent it to backers via Dropbox.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WORTHY OF A CULT FOLLOWING
Super Troopers. Veronica Mars. Mystery Science
Theater 3000. These reboot campaigns arguably all
have cult followings of loyal fans. Accessing that fan
base through rewards can be difficult to do correctly
because it requires you to know your audience inside
and out in order to plan and price well. If you’re the
creator of the project, you are probably already an
expert. But it does help to do social media research to
see what fans are saying about your project’s subject
matter. You can also read all the comment boards and
blogs of the superfans to survey the crowd.
With the PonoPlayer campaign (chapter 2), for
instance, the Pono team was able to tap into
superfans by offering special artist signature series of
the PonoPlayer with laser-engraved autographs from
bands like Arcade Fire and Crosby, Stills & Nash. I
believe that by tailoring the product toward subsets of
fans, they were able to capitalize on appealing to
those bands’ audiences.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
NOSTALGIC
Depending on your audience and project, there might
be an opportunity to offer a reward that’s nostalgic for
backers. You just have to brainstorm what people
might be pining for from the past.
The two standards manual campaigns were
nostalgic. For the NYCTA manual, we told the story
about how confusing the subway system used to be
before standards were developed in the ’70s,
emphasizing what a tremendous moment in history
that was. For the NASA manual, we were trying to
bring back a graphic identity that many people loved
and recognized from the ’70s and ’80s.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
APPEALING
We see so many campaigns that launch without really
considering their brand image and design. You could
have a very useful product, but if people think it
doesn’t look good, they won’t pledge for it. Include
beautiful photos of your rewards, and leverage the
video to show off your product in the best way
possible.
For the NYCTA manual, we included a long scroll of
photos of the original book at the end of our campaign
page. You could really get a sense for how special the
pages were. It was book porn. We knew that a lot of
the support we got came from readers being able to
check out the gorgeous interior online before backing
the project.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
ACCESSIBLE
Backers want access to project creators, regardless of
whether they’re celebrities or not. You’re creating a
community, and your campaign should underscore the
fact that you’re all in this together. A great way to
connect with backers is by giving them special
(limited!) access to you through rewards.
With Bellingcat, for example, we offered a special
opportunity to Skype one-on-one with Eliot. If you’re
funding a film, you could invite backers to a screening.
If you have a tech campaign, you could offer the
chance for a backer to go to lunch with you and get
your advice on their investor pitch.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SIMPLE AND TRANSPARENT
Be clear and to-the-point when you describe each
reward on your campaign page. If the text is long,
backers could get confused and then disinterested.
Keep it simple. Backers should know exactly what
they’re getting when they pledge. You’ll also want to
be up-front and include any disclaimers (for example,
about taxes) right in the description of each reward.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
MORE TIPS FROM THE CROWDFUNDING
TRENCHES
Understanding how to handle budgeting and rewards
is huge. Once you have those under control, you’ll be
well on your way to planning a great campaign. Here
are some of the important lessons my team and I
learned along the way.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
DON’T JUST BE A CREATOR, BE A BACKER
Show that you’re part of the community by backing
other projects on your crowdfunding platform, if you
haven’t already. You’ll create goodwill with other
creators and show you value the process and
community.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SOCIAL MEDIA FOLLOWERS DO NOT EQUAL DOLLARS
Just because someone involved in your campaign has
a big social media following doesn’t automatically
mean those followers will become backers. When we
were planning to run a campaign for the documentary
Motivation 2.0, which follows legendary skateboarder
Chris Cole, we thought funding would be
straightforward: the trailer was awesome, the director
is an amazing filmmaker, and Chris Cole has a large,
active fan base of about 1.7 million followers on
Facebook, over 300,000 on Twitter, and some
800,000 on Instagram. We also locked in influencer
support from pro-skaters like Tony Hawk. On Launch
Day, we had a social reach in the far millions, but it
wasn’t converting. We realized that most of the
followers we were reaching were kids and teens
without credit cards. By the end of the campaign, we
reached our goal, but it was tough and required a ton
of rethinking and grunt work. My team learned just
how important it is to spend time up front, before
launching, to get to know your audience and have a
sense of whether they are willing and able to pledge
money online. This can be a risk not only with a very
young audience, but also with some older audiences
who may be unfamiliar with the crowdfunding space
as well.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
BE PREPARED TO SHARE YOUR PRODUCT
If you’re working on a tech or design product and you
want it to be covered by the media (note: you do),
make sure to get a working prototype that you can
show to journalists well in advance. We have found
that press is not as interested in writing about your
project simply because it’s launching on a
crowdfunding platform. (In fact, they might just ignore
you if that’s your pitch.) Offer to give a demo of the
product so they can see it in action, or send them a
prototype to test out themselves, and pitch it with
great materials and a story (more on that in the next
chapter). That way, it will be a product review or
product launch story rather than just a crowdfunding
launch story.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
FUNDRAISING FATIGUE IS REAL
Consider how often your target audience is asked to
donate to a project or cause, and when they were last
asked to pledge money. When creators who’ve
recently run a crowdfunding campaign come back to
me and want to run a second one—to further develop
their product or to launch another product to the same
audience—I generally recommend that we wait at
least a year. You can’t expect people to open their
wallets and fund you again so quickly. Fundraising
fatigue is real, and you need to be sensitive to
backers’ generosity and willingness to give.
If you’re working with an organization that often
runs multiple fundraisers, be cognizant of timing. Also,
never run your crowdfunding campaign at the same
time or right before or after another fundraiser. Some
nonprofits, for instance, may run several fundraisers
every year, and by and large go back to the same
group of people each time for donations.
Understandably, these donors will probably suffer
from being hit up with repeat donation requests. In
these cases, you need to not only time your campaign
carefully, but you’ll probably also want to plan a
strategy to reach a wider audience. You’re likely going
to need to expand on your existing base, so start your
research early to reach beyond them.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
YOU HAVE DATA: USE IT
Once you launch, make sure to follow all the data that
comes in. It’s really valuable! Both Kickstarter and
Indiegogo (as well as other crowdfunding platforms)
have dashboards that come to life with data, charts,
and information. Don’t overlook it. You’ll be able to
track things like:
Referrals. You can find out how your backers are
ending up on your page, whether it’s through social
media, the crowdfunding platform itself, or another
source, like a big article about you in the press.
Analytics. Kickstarter and Indiegogo allow you to
connect to Google Analytics. Indiegogo enables
campaign owners to track referrals using custom
URLs. On Indiegogo, if you’re using digital marketing
strategies, you can also use conversion and
remarketing pixels to follow what’s happening with
your Google AdWords and Facebook paid placements.
(Conversion and retargeting pixels are website scripts
provided by ad platforms—like Facebook and Google
—to advertisers. Basically, they allow the advertising
platform to follow particular actions made by website
visitors.)
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Rewards popularity. Check out which rewards are
popular and consider how you can add similar ones
mid-campaign to re-energize your audience and keep
funding coming in.
Backers. We make it a daily practice to comb through
backer lists to see who’s contributing to a campaign.
You might find an influencer in the industry who can
contribute to your campaign in a bigger way.
Overall, these tools and features are evolving all the
time, so read up on what your platform has to offer,
and take advantage of it.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SEND A PRE-CAMPAIGN SURVEY
Doing a survey can be particularly helpful if you’re
crowdfunding a product and need to better
understand how to price it in your campaign. Through
a free tool like SurveyMonkey or Google Forms, you
can design a survey and send it to your audience
(collect those email addresses!) to assess:
Price sensitivity. Segment your audience into two
groups. Send one group a survey about your product
at one price point, and the other group another price
point. Ask how likely each group is to buy the product
and how likely they are to refer it to a friend—an
important measuring stick in crowdfunding, where
campaign sharing is essential. You’ll have a better
sense of how you can price your product for your
campaign.
Feature preference. Learn which product features are
most appealing to your audience by asking them to
rank or respond to features. It will help you determine
what to prioritize on your campaign page, or even on
social media, in pitches, and in ads.
Audience characteristics. If you include a few
questions to collect information about your audience’s
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
demographics, like age, interests, and location, for
example, you can later use that data in digital
marketing.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
BE CAREFUL WITH BIG NAMES
Having a celebrity or “big name” associated with your
campaign can be a double-edged sword. While it
draws a lot of attention to the project, potential
backers may be skeptical of finances. They might
assume the campaign will automatically succeed
because of the attention it’s getting, so why should
they pledge? Or they might be thinking: “Why can’t
(insert celebrity name) fund this themselves? Why do
they need crowdfunding? They’re already rich.”
Our response to this is that crowdfunding is not just
about money, but about building a crowd. Be sure to
explain on the campaign page (and in the press, if it
comes up) why you’re crowdfunding, including that
you are fostering a community and want to involve
early adopters and backers whose voices and support
matter.
Celebrity campaigns can also draw negative press.
My advice? When it comes to negative press, we
usually don’t respond directly to it because it’s
typically not productive. Instead, we always make sure
our clients are prepared for challenging questions from
the press, so we can articulate and control (to some
extent) our story.
When you have a big name involved in your project,
it also can be tempting to exploit their celebrity. But
be careful with overextending someone, and try to
make their involvement exclusive. If you’re doing
experiential rewards, like a Skype or dinner meeting
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
with the celebrity, offer a small, limited number. It will
increase the reward’s value and protect the person’s
time.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
EXPECT A MID-CAMPAIGN SLUMP (AND KNOW IF YOU NEED TO
PIVOT)
For nearly all our crowdfunding campaigns, pledges
follow an inverse bell curve. Funding will come in
more substantially at the beginning and end of a
campaign and thin out in the middle. I wish there were
some magic tip that could steer your campaign clear
of this slump, but I have found that it’s just a natural
thing that happens during campaigns.
That said, don’t just sit back in your campaign’s
middle weeks and pray the funding will pick up again
in the last few days. Keep on pushing—and know if
you need to pivot. If your campaign truly is not getting
traction, or if you notice some red flags—say, your
influencer strategy or your Day 1 press is not
converting—you may need to change directions. This
is when we come together as a team and plan mini
campaigns. Here are some strategies we use.
• Re-evaluate your audience. Research who
has backed you so far. Are they on Twitter?
Instagram? What do they read? What do
they like? Find more opportunities that align
with your audience.
• Invest in digital marketing to attract people
in a different way. (More on that in the next
chapter.)
• Change your pitch and create a fresh angle
that will resonate with what you’ve learned
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
about your backers. Always continue to find
and pitch new press outlets.
• Find and collaborate with new influencers.
• Value your existing backers. Update them
with great content that continues to connect
them to your project and makes them want
to share it with their friends.
• Release exciting new rewards. Study which
rewards have been popular so far and think
of creative ways to add more.
• Find a pledge matching partner. This can be
a funder who believes in your cause and
creates an offering where if you hit a certain
amount, he/she will match it.
• Network with other creators. Back other
campaigns.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
THE FIRST DAY SLUMP
Depending on your product’s price point, your mid-
campaign slump may happen much sooner—say if it’s
for a very high-priced tech item like a digital fabrication
tool (3D printer or CNC mill type projects), which can
sometimes start around $1,000. I have learned that
instead of a huge spike at the beginning, projects like
these have a tendency to build over the span of the
campaign with a more gradual funding trajectory.
Why? Because backers might not impulsively pledge
for something so expensive. They need time to
consider it before making the commitment (or get
approval from their bosses).
In these situations, creators need to generate a
sense of trust to encourage backers to make that
investment. How? Great transparency and
communication. One strategy is to produce several
demo videos showing the product in action, as well as
adding more diagrams, GIFs, and images to the
campaign page. You can also deepen your reach
online and in person. Attend events, like trade shows,
to show off your product and answer questions about
it. Show it off to relevant press outlets. Enlist new
influencers or try Google and Facebook ads targeted
toward your audience’s interests.
While this is not the case for all these types of
campaigns, they can potentially be a slow burn,
requiring extra communication, coverage, and
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
demoing. But with these extra efforts, the last few
days can get a big bump, and the final result can be
incredibly satisfying.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
BE COMMUNICATIVE AND OPEN
Remember that backers are not investors. They are
donating money to your effort, so be good to them.
Post updates about progress, and be gracious about
and thankful for support. Be honest about the risks
and challenges you might face, and how you plan to
overcome them. Be clear about the rewards: backers
should know exactly what they’re getting and when.
Be sure to include a section explaining the
components in a budget. It’s so important that
backers understand where their money is going.
In the post-campaign phase, communication
continues. If you find yourself facing fulfillment delays
when your campaign wraps, you need to explain what
the problem is, apologize, and share your plan for
finding a solution. A crowdfunding campaign is a work
in progress, and you can let your backers know that
you are learning along the way, too.
If you’re not communicative, backers might become
skeptical of your ability to deliver, and then angry.
People may voice their concerns publicly in comments
on your page. Some could even get nasty and start
asking for refunds if you go silent or don’t
communicate about why there are delays.
But you can avoid that by being open and having fun
with post-campaign updates. While producing your
product, share photos or videos of the production
facility, or keep backers posted on your film’s
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
screenings in nearby cities. Updates make backers
feel involved in the process.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
NASTY COMMENTS WILL HAPPEN
This is the Internet. Backers can be passionate. And
get pissed. Because they believe in your project
enough to give money to it, they’re probably also
going to have opinions about it. Even if you have
produced a great product, backers might still be
disappointed about a reward when they receive it, for
example, and leave negative comments. I always
respond to backers who have constructive feedback
or questions and thank those who are positive. I find
that nasty, unfounded comments are not worth
responding to or losing sleep over.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
EXPECT DELAYS
Be very conservative with the delivery dates you
provide for each reward. Everything will probably take
longer than you expect. Just like you’ll add a cushion
to your budget, you’ll want to add a cushion to your
fulfillment timeline. It’s better to under-promise and
over-deliver than the opposite. But on top of that, be
sure to also speak to your production partners to get a
clear understanding of their timeline. If you’re
producing a book, talk to the printer; if you’re finishing
a film, talk to your producer. Get your answers about
delivery dates from the people making the thing for
you, and then add a cushion.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
BE PROACTIVE ABOUT RECONCILING
PAYMENTS
On Indiegogo, backers’ credit cards are charged at the
time of purchase. On Kickstarter, credit cards are
charged right when a successful campaign ends. At
that point, some payments won’t go through (if a
credit card has expired, for example), so you need to
reconcile them. On the dashboard, you will find a list
of errored payments in the backer report. Kickstarter
gives each backer time to correct the error, and sends
periodic reminders to backers with errored payments.
We find it is worth sending backers personal emails to
collect payments, too. No harm in extra efforts!
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
YOU MAY NEED TO REFUND
Once a successful Kickstarter or Indiegogo campaign
is over, you may consider refunding some backers if
they are dissatisfied, even if it might not be mandatory
to do so. Because remember that you are building
your brand, and you want to maintain a great
relationship with supporters.
When Hamish and I ran a successful Kickstarter
campaign to fund a poster of all 469 NYC subway
stops, some posters were damaged during the
shipping process, and a handful of backers didn’t like
them. When backers let us know, we quickly shipped
out new posters or refunded them. It was money lost
on our end, but we wanted to show good customer
service and avoid negative feedback. Plus, this is one
reason why all campaign budgets should include a
buffer—things go wrong, and you’ll need that money
to fix them.
Since I’ve made these mistakes and learned these
lessons, I hope you won’t have to. Nonetheless, in
crowdfunding—just like anything else—there are
bound to be bumps in the road. My best advice is to
invest time up front researching and preparing, then
keep a positive attitude for the ride! There are
solutions for almost everything.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Chapter 7
The Power of Press and
Influencers
When I started out running crowdfunding campaigns,
I didn’t know the first thing about getting press or
doing social media and what they had to do with
crowdfunding. Now, I can’t imagine doing my job
without them. The strategies I develop with my team
for each campaign are getting more extensive all the
time. The work demands it. Big-name companies
increasingly use crowdfunding, and they tend to come
armed with tremendous resources for every aspect of
a campaign, such as advertising, publicity, and social
media. But you don’t have to be a trained publicist or
social media manager to do this work. It’s something I
learned how to do on the job, without formal training,
and all the tactics I use are ones creators like you can
use, too. You just need to know how.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WHY SPEND TIME ON PRESS AND SOCIAL
MEDIA?
Here’s the thing: getting press for your campaign and
reaching people through social media is essential. The
concept is simple: successful campaigns are the result
of having a crowd that will fund you. Your friends and
family are, in most cases, not a big enough crowd. To
access a bigger crowd, you have to get more eyes on
your project, and reaching people through press
coverage and social media are two fundamental and
highly effective ways of doing that. Plus, this part of
crowdfunding can be incredibly fun. It’s a chance to be
creative, think outside the box, expand your network,
and build your community.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PRESS 101
“Getting press” means having your crowdfunding
campaign receive media attention, whether it’s
featured in an article, mentioned in a podcast,
reviewed on a well-known blog, talked about on a TV
show, or any number of other options. At Vann
Alexandra, my team and I typically target online press
(vs. traditional print press like newspapers, radio
shows, and magazines). We want people to see these
stories online, where it’s easy to click or tap a link and
go straight over to the campaign page to pledge. Plus,
securing online press requires a shorter lead time—a
good fit for speedy crowdfunding prep.
It was only a few years ago that launching your
dream project or product through crowdfunding was a
novelty. Just the fact that you were using a
crowdfunding platform to get funding was a fresh and
exciting angle—and as a result, it was easier to get
journalists to pay attention. Now, everyone is
crowdfunding. The landscape has completely
changed. It’s probably not enough to go to a journalist
and say, “Check out this cool project that’s being
crowdfunded!” You need to be able to clearly state
what makes your project newsworthy and what sets
you apart from other founders and creators out there.
Ask yourself, Am I pitching an idea that I would want
to read about?
For most projects, our press strategy before a
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
campaign launch looks like this:
• Create a press kit complete with a press
release, bios, talking points from the client,
and hi-res images. The talking points are
sort of like a Q&A: we send clients
questions to answer to explain their product,
process, or methodology in more granular
detail in their voice. Journalists can pull from
this for stories they write. We typically store
the whole press kit in an easily shareable
online folder like WeTransfer, Dropbox, or
Google Drive so it’s at our fingertips.
• Research appropriate outlets and audiences
for a campaign.
• Develop strong media stories around the
campaign to get people excited.
• Pitch top-tier media outlets and relevant
blogs.
After the campaign launches, our press strategy
often evolves depending on how the project is doing,
how people are talking about it online, and which
media outlets show interest. As the campaign
progresses, we continue to look for new markets to
hit and continue to pitch publications along the way.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
FINDING AND REFINING YOUR STORY
Reporters are busy, managing overloaded email
inboxes and following (and dropping) a ton of different
leads. I find that one of the keys to securing press is
making it easy for reporters to share your story by
doing the hard work for them and sending a
newsworthy story that’s relevant.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
If the Idea of “Getting Press” Overwhelms or Intimidates
You, It’s Okay to Start Small
Campaigns will generally benefit from media
attention, regardless of your project or funding
goal. But you don’t have to go straight for the
cover of Time.
• Start where you are, with local press.
(Your hometown community can be a
great source of support!)
• Reach out to bloggers with smaller,
niche followings.
• Ask around. Do your friends know
journalists who will cover your project?
• Consider developing a small budget for
paid press or advertising. (But do your
research first, so you’re confident you’ll
get your money’s worth.)
• Prepare early and go big! Keep reading
—I’ll show you how.
The story (stories, really) you develop for press will
be similar to your campaign’s story, but it needs to go
above and beyond the basics of having a cool product
or project and funding it.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
In 2015, we worked on a Kickstarter campaign with
Axel Audio. The company had developed a novel type
of headphones that used what they called
“Soundscapes” to customize users’ listening
experience. Using a special web application, Axel
could analyze a person’s listening preferences based
on their Spotify behavior to determine their preferred
soundscape—Pure, Deep, and Core—which could be
used to customize the headphones’ sound. The
headphones were also modular and customizable—
they came with different on-ear or over-ear speakers
you could choose from, as well as foldable and
detachable headbands, soft headband inserts, and
different color cables. Starting at $99, the headphones
would be marketed to all kinds of people who cared
about sound quality and comfort.
We were really drawn to the product because we
hadn’t seen one like it. We also loved the team, a
family-run company of incredibly ambitious and kind
people. In the weeks leading up to the campaign
launch date, we worked with a publicist for additional
support. Our filmmaking partner RAVA also put
together a gorgeous video. The page was ready to go
with clean explanatory text and cool graphics. We
were excited.
Then, just over a week before we were scheduled
to launch, a company came out with a similar product:
modular headphones with different types of
headbands, earpads, on-ear or over-ear options, and
cables. “The modular headphones have arrived,” an
article proclaimed, and the press—like Engadget,
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WIRED, Co.Design, NBCNews, and others—lined up
to cover the new headphones.
We found ourselves in a really tough spot. The
publicist reported back that with a new competitor on
the scene, press wasn’t biting at pitches the way
we’d hoped. Some reporters would reply saying they
already covered a product just like it the week before.
We spoke to our client and decided to push back our
scheduled launch date another few days. We needed
to put our heads together to reposition ourselves and
reconsider our approach.
With a competitor in the market, we had to
differentiate our product. We set out to understand
exactly how Axel was distinct from its new
competitor, and the team made a chart that compared
product features side-by-side. We realized that the
features had differences across the board. Axel had
foldable headbands, for example, which was
perceived as pretty important for many listeners, and
the competitor didn’t. We also noticed that the
competitor seemed to be marketing to DJs, but Axel
wanted to position itself as accessible to a broad
audience. Significantly, Axel offered Soundscapes,
which were really interesting on the technology side.
On top of all that, one of the biggest differences was
that Axel headphones were less expensive. (Note:
Price differences are important to customers! It can
really help to focus on price, when it works to your
advantage.)
We had our key product differentiators to work
with, but we didn’t stop there. Pitches were
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
repositioned to focus on the trend angle of modular
headphones. Now that there were two new modular
headphones hitting the market, they were seen as
trending. Axel and its competitor were at the forefront
of the new market, and it made them a stronger topic
in the industry—something important to cover.
We also leveraged Axel’s company story. The
company was founded by a Korean family, the Ohs.
Sam Oh, the father and company president, had come
to the United States in the early 1980s with almost
nothing. When he arrived he got a Walkman and
headphones and became a door-to-door salesman; he
always kept the Walkman with him, listening to music
while he worked. Eventually, Sam Oh started his own
multinational consumer electronics corporation, which
became a leader in the industry. As Sam and his wife
raised their children, Kevin and Samantha, Sam filled
their world with music. After working in electronics for
almost thirty years, Sam saw an opportunity to change
the way high-quality audio products were made.
Together with his children, Sam started Axel Audio.
We pitched their family story with a human interest
angle to publications, which got some traction. After
retooling our approach and focusing on differentiators,
the trend angle, and the human interest story, we
were able to secure press. (The Ohs themselves did a
lot of pitching, too—we were in this together!)
Eventually Uncrate, Supercompressor, Digital Trends,
and PSFK all wrote about Axel.
The project received its best press piece in T
magazine later on; the piece included this opening
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
sentence: “The just-launched headphones brand Axel
Audio is a family affair.”
In the end, it took everyone involved to get Axel the
press we all knew it deserved, but we got there, and
ended up surpassing our goal to reach over $200,000.
The project underscored for me how important it is
to have a story that is different from competitors’
stories, and one that is newsworthy.
It’s not good enough just to have a great product.
All “great product” stories need to have an added
dimension in order to work.
These storytelling strategies are not just product
based; campaigns for films, music, design, and others
can follow similar techniques. For a film project, for
example, think about what makes your story different:
Are you a first-time filmmaker? Why are you so special
compared to the other first-time filmmakers? What in
your history makes you qualified to do this film in
particular? Have you or your past films won any
awards? What makes your film’s subject matter
relevant right now? What connects your project to
what’s going on in the world today?
If you think about multiple angles before launching,
you’ll be better prepared to secure great press—even
if you’re faced with an unexpected market change,
like we were with Axel Audio.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PUBLICITY SCHEDULE
Now, let’s walk through a typical publicity schedule.
Heads up: the tasks themselves are more important
than the exact timing, and the schedule for each
campaign looks a little different each time—and that’s
fine! You can also find a detailed schedule in the
Resources section at the close of the book.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
DOING PRESS RESEARCH: 8 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
So you have a great project and a great story. Now
what? How do you get them into the hands of the
right people? It takes some research and—something
I have a complicated relationship with—spreadsheets!
Nice, friendly, well-organized spreadsheets. I’ll show
you what I mean.
First, get ready to spend a lot of time on Google.
Start looking up companies, creators, crowdfunding
campaigns, products, competitors, online forums and
communities, and stories that connect to your project
and story. For example, with Axel Audio, this would
mean getting a complete understanding of the
headphones landscape. What are the industry trends
in mobile listening? Who’s writing about headphones
and what do they have to say? What are the most
popular brands and top-selling headphones out there
right now? How much do they cost?
A lot of this research will help you develop your
story, enabling you to highlight how it’s newsworthy.
If a narrative has already been used, you’ll know to
bring a fresh perspective to the campaign. For
example, the story of new “modular headphones”
was already played out when we launched the Axel
campaign, but the Soundscapes and the story of the
family-run business were different.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
The Launch Day Exclusive
An “exclusive” is an article that breaks the story
—your campaign launch—on Launch Day. We
always try to secure an exclusive for our
campaigns to guarantee attention and traction
immediately when a campaign goes live. Having a
huge publication—say the New York Times—
write about your story the morning you launch
gets people talking. It’s a powerful way to kick off
your project.
There’s something in it for the journalist, too.
They get to be the first one to break the news.
When considering a publication that might be a
good candidate for your exclusive, think of it like
your reach school—you want the best publication
possible. But it should also make sense for your
project. Billboard probably would not have been
tempted to break the news about our Bellingcat
campaign.
When you pitch a journalist on your story, state
outright that you’re offering them an exclusive.
Always ask the journalist to include the link to the
campaign, and definitely ask them to hold the
piece until your campaign is live. What you are
asking is for them to embargo the piece until a
certain time. Once the campaign is live on Launch
Day, your exclusive will go up first. Any other
press you’ve secured must then wait for your
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
green light before going live, in order not to break
the exclusive. This needs to be managed
carefully. Make sure other publications don’t go
live before your exclusive does.
This process will also allow you to learn the press
landscape, understanding which publications and
outlets—and even which journalists—cover your topic.
This is the information you’ll want to compile in a
spreadsheet of leads.
The more specific you can be in your research, the
better. We start by identifying a long list of
publications relevant to the project at hand. For tech or
design, we might begin with publications like Wired,
Fast Company, TechCrunch, Gizmodo, Cool Hunting,
designboom, Design Milk, Core 77, Uncrate, AIGA’s
Eye on Design, and Quartz. Film could be Indiewire,
Filmmaker magazine, Buzzfeed, Entertainment
Weekly, Variety, Deadline, etc.
Once we have our list (aiming for at least fifty or so
entries), we try to find a specific journalist at each one.
We look for reporters who have covered the subject
matter before, preferably more than once—maybe it’s
even their beat or specialty. We try to find personal or
direct work email addresses online. And again, we
avoid using an “info” email, like books@nytimes.com.
Then we do some deeper brainstorming. We add a
column in the spreadsheet for notes about what angle
we can use for each individual journalist, showing why
s/he in particular would be interested in our campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
We add links to a past article or two of theirs so that
later we can cite this writing history as a connection to
our project, and to show we’ve done our research.
It is essential to have a press strategy because so
many people don’t. Journalists have inboxes full of
emails that are sent without enough thought and care.
I have heard from some journalist friends that pitches
sometimes have typos or are too long or the person
writing it has accidentally left another journalist’s
name or leftover formatting from a previous email.
Bad! (And seriously, strip the formatting so it’s not
obvious you’re copying and pasting the same email to
a bunch of people.) Putting time, attention to detail,
and research into this process is essential to getting
the results you want. You should start the research
process at least two months before launching if you
can. Trust me, it pays off.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
CREATING THE PRESS RELEASE: 3 TO 4 WEEKS BEFORE
LAUNCH
As you research press and fine-tune your media story
(with multiple angles), you’ll also start putting together
a press release.
Working in crowdfunding, I’ve written so many
press releases. On my very first campaign, though, it
was only when my collaborator, Tim, asked if we
needed one that I realized press releases are
important tools. Flash forward to the present day, and
now I consider creating an amazing press release a
critical step.
A press release is like a summary of your project,
brand, and story. You’ll use it to communicate with
press in a succinct, clear fashion, so everyone has all
the same facts, and so your story is explained in a
consistent manner.
A strong release gives the reader the necessary
basics:
• Key information (What is the campaign all
about?)
• Background (Who? What? Where?)
• An understanding of a campaign’s relevance
and importance (Why is this compelling and
important now?)
• Campaign information (Link to the campaign,
platform, duration, rewards and prices,
product specifications)
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
• Contact information
My favorite press releases are the ones with a
narrative arc. This is the tactic we used for the NYCTA
Graphics Standards Manual release: we focused on
the story behind the manual and its rich connection to
New York history and design history. It also included
access to all the necessary campaign information,
quotes, and specifications of the book. It worked so
well that we used a similar approach when we
launched the NASA manual campaign a year later. See
the NASA manual release and an example from
another campaign in the Resources.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
ANATOMY OF A GREAT PRESS RELEASE
In my experience, these are the characteristics of a
great press release:
• Your pitch should be in the title.
• In the beginning, explain your project within
two strong lines, and stress the urgency and
relevance of the project.
• Tell a story through your press release.
Imagine that you’re walking the journalist
through your project’s journey.
• Include quotes from the creators and/or
partners.
• Try to keep the press release to one page in
length, except for, say, bios and images.
(I’m sure not every publicist stresses this,
but we do.)
• Make it visual. A second page can even be
used for just images. (And then also attach a
hi-res media kit of the images separately.)
• Get it designed! We typically have a
designer create a polished PDF.
• Include your launch dates, campaign period,
campaign goal, the best rewards you are
offering (as well as their prices), and contact
information for your team’s press contacts.
(Refer to the five essential elements of a
strong press release listed above.)
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full: • For a product, include its specifications.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
WRITING THE PERFECT PITCH: 2 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Raymond Carver is one of my favorite writers. The
way he approached his short stories under his editor,
Gordon Lish—using terse and impressively tight
sentences that were still descriptive and powerful—is
relevant to the importance of good writing in
crowdfunding. In place of fifteen words, for example,
Lish would maybe tell Carver to only use five.
Attention spans on the Internet are short. In a
matter of seconds, we need to catch the attention of
someone scrolling through their Twitter feed, a
reporter opening an email from a stranger, or
someone visiting a campaign page for the first time.
It’s so important to be concise and clear in all forms of
writing around a campaign, but especially when
reaching out to press. In other words, learn from the
late great Raymond Carver and use five words instead
of fifteen!
When I cold-pitched a science reporter at the New
York Times about the NASA manual, I tried to keep it
snappy. I introduced myself and established my
credibility in the first few lines. Then I shared
information about the manual and its reissue. I
mentioned the names of our clients (who had massive
success with the Standards Manual) and the support
we had from the manual’s designer. I ended the pitch
with recent press about the manual to make it seem
particularly timely and relevant (serendipitously, there
had been great press about the old NASA logo just
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
weeks before we started pitching), and I also included
previous coverage around the logo in the New York
Times. I attached a bunch of scans of the manual and
their captions, too.
I heard back from the writer in less than 30 minutes.
He ended up breaking the story both online and in
print in the New York Times the day we launched our
campaign. You can find my pitch email in the
Resources section at the end of this book.
Our pitching style is always evolving. Sometimes
we start with a pre-pitch—a punchy email we hope
will get journalists’ attention even before we send a
full pitch. We make these emails super short, casual,
and even mysterious. And we include strong visuals.
Those help a lot. If this isn’t your first rodeo, you
should go back to journalists that you have
successfully pitched in the past since you have built
that relationship.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
BRINGING IT ALL TOGETHER
I always recommend aiming for as much press as
possible for Launch Day (at least a few strong pieces).
Sometimes a client asks if we should spread out the
press over the duration of the campaign, but I say no,
go gangbusters right away!
The first thing to do is start emailing your pitches for
online media at least 10 days before your scheduled
launch date—not so far in advance that it doesn’t
seem urgent to journalists, but not so close that you
don’t have enough time to line up media.
After you lock in your exclusive, prioritize the
remaining journalists in your spreadsheet and pitch
them accordingly. Some may want to cover the story
only if they have the exclusive (or some version of an
exclusive—exclusive images, videos, interviews.)
On Launch Day, contact the journalist who is
breaking the story to let them know the campaign is
live. After they have a chance to make the
announcement first, let the other journalists know
they can publish their stories. Hopefully, all this
coverage will also be picked up by other publications.
Throughout the campaign, keep pitching away. As
you get coverage, you’ll likely tap out a certain
narrative and need to move on to a new one in order
to stay relevant and keep gaining new audiences.
Continue to refine your story with new and updated
press releases, and hit up new publications that could
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
be interested in the subject matter. You want to keep
getting traffic to the page, so push for more press.
Once your campaign ends, be sure to send
journalists who gave you coverage an update on the
campaign’s success, along with a big thank you. (You
may be pitching them again!) You can also thank
journalists on social media by posting their articles
with a nice shout-out, and you can thank them in
updates or on your campaign page.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
The Evolution of a Pitch
In early 2015, we launched a Kickstarter to
crowdfund the final album for one of the best girl
groups of all time, TLC. What was so amazing is
that the campaign raised a whopping $430,255
without having released any music—the group’s
incredible and loyal fan base, as well as the
massive amount of press and momentum around
the campaign, carried it to success.
One of the coolest things about this project
was that we were able to present press with a
totally new pitch midway through the campaign.
Here’s what happened.
We were offering a great set of experiential
rewards, one of which was a sleepover with
either Chilli or T-Boz from the group. One day
when we were scrolling through the backer
report (which you should always do to see who is
backing your project), we saw the name Katy
Perry. I shrieked, “Is this real?” We called TLC’s
manager, who spoke to the group’s publicist. He
called Perry’s agent, and it was confirmed. It was
the perfect new story to generate mid-campaign
interest in the project. Pretty quickly, Billboard,
People, ET, Us magazine, Daily Mail, Business
Insider, MTV, and more were sharing the story.
The day word got out about Katy Perry’s support
ended up being the day more funds came in than
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
any other day throughout the campaign.
After you work hard to get as much press
around launch, find creative ways to go back to
press with new, exciting stories by keeping a
close eye on your backer report and on influencer
involvement.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SOCIAL MEDIA 101
The social media landscape is continually evolving.
Platforms, services, and communities change rapidly
and constantly. But it boils down to this: social media
is about connecting with people online, and that’s
exactly what crowdfunding is about, too. Social media,
in all its forms, for all its flaws and powers, is a tool for
forming community. That’s what makes it so
important to the success of your campaign.
Regardless of how the technical structures and
components of social media change over time, the
foundation of effective communication online won’t.
In all of our social media strategies, we strive to
communicate in ways that are relevant, clear and
concise, engaging and actionable, and visual and
interesting.
For most projects, before a campaign launches, we
develop a social media campaign by finding and
partnering with influencers on Facebook, Twitter,
and/or other platforms relevant to our campaign and
audience. We also create a plan of who will share
content (us, the client, influencers), when it will be
posted (how often and at what time of day), and what
will be shared (we write sample posts, talk about
hashtags and formatting, etc.). We also share other
tips—for example, if you haven’t posted in awhile, up
the frequency of your posts to repopulate the page
before getting into a regular posting groove.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
During the campaign, just like for press, our tactics
evolve depending on what’s happening with the
campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
SOCIAL MEDIA SCHEDULE
Here’s a typical social media schedule. With social
media, much of the timing depends on the current
status of your accounts, like if you already have an
engaged audience or if you need to build one from
scratch. (If it’s the latter, you probably will need to
spend a lot more time up front.) You can also find a
detailed schedule in the Resources section.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
STARTING CAMPAIGN-SPECIFIC SOCIAL MEDIA ACCOUNTS: 8+
WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH (THE MORE TIME THE BETTER!)
If you don’t already have social media accounts set up
specifically for your project, product, or business, I’d
recommend getting them going as soon as possible. It
takes a while for people to discover you and for you to
build followers. Choose handles/usernames that are
simple and obvious for your project. For the NYCTA
manual, we created @standardsmanual on Twitter and
Instagram (keep the names the same across
platforms); for the Joan Didion documentary we went
with @didiondoc on Twitter and Instagram (more on
that campaign and process in the next chapter). If you
already have specific accounts set up, you’ll stick with
and leverage those (Axel Audio, for example, already
had @axelheadphones). If you even have a personal
account with an engaged and bigger following,
definitely stick with that too.
Set up multiple social media accounts with the
same handle—ideally one on as many channels as you
can support, but be realistic.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
CONSIDER YOUR AUDIENCE
Know where your audience is congregating. You can
get an understanding of this partly through research
and partly through experimenting.
Research. Go online and check out the posts and
conversations happening on different social media
platforms. Does there seem to be more relevant
activity on one than others? This will help you prioritize
where to focus your efforts.
Experiment. When we started social media accounts
for the Joan Didion documentary project, we began
with Twitter and Instagram. Instagram almost
immediately felt like a more natural fit because we
had great visuals (like rare photos of Didion). The more
time we spent on it, the more people we found
posting about Joan Didion, responding to our
comments, sharing photos, and creating a community
with us. The engagement rate was much higher than
it was on Twitter. It became obvious that Instagram
would be a key player in our strategy for that
campaign.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
CONSIDER YOURSELF
Which platforms do you already use? Start where you
are. If you’ve spent the last five years as a filmmaker
and now you’re crowdfunding a documentary, you’re
probably already connected with filmmaking
communities in one way or another. For the Bellingcat
project, Eliot was already extremely active on Twitter
and had an audience of thousands of loyal followers.
The conversations he was having were already about
investigative journalism topics—directly related to our
project—so it was natural to primarily leverage Twitter
to promote the campaign.
How much time do you have? Nothing looks worse
than a Twitter feed that hasn’t been updated in
months or a Facebook page that’s blank. Think about
how much time you have to dedicate—right now,
before you launch—and choose the top few platforms
you can realistically actively manage.
At Vann Alexandra, for most campaigns, we prefer
to use some combination of Facebook, Twitter,
Instagram, and YouTube. Other platforms worth
considering include Tumblr, LinkedIn, and Snapchat. In
general, we view Facebook as the best platform to
connect with users and the easiest to advertise with;
you don’t have a character count and it’s pretty
straightforward to implement. Twitter is a great tool
for connecting with journalists and tuning into news
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
and trends, and it’s ideal for finding influencers; it’s
easy to see who is at the center of conversations and
who has a lot of engaged followers. Instagram is great
for a visually oriented audience, and it’s perfect for
reading comment threads where you can find
influencers, too.
Not only is social media critical for connecting with
your audience, but it’s also an amazing tool for
learning about your audience—from what they read to
how old they are to the language they use in posts to
the key players they interact with. Social media allows
you to learn about your community as a whole and
about the people within it.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
GETTING FOLLOWERS
There’s no exact science to getting followers. Your
technique will depend on your existing audience, the
time you have, and your budget. Here are two ways to
grow your following.
Organically. This is the best way! Put in the time and
effort to find people to follow, @-mention them, like
their posts, comment on their posts, and engage with
them in hopes they’ll check out your account and then
follow you.
Advertising. Almost every social media platform will
allow you to advertise on it. Facebook and Twitter
have some user-friendly, economical options that will
allow you to target a pretty precise audience (e.g., by
location, gender, age group, and interest). Ads can be
a great way to grow your following quickly.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
THE IMPORTANCE OF INFLUENCERS: 4 TO 8+ WEEKS BEFORE
LAUNCH
Getting influencers on board is a really effective
strategy we use to get more eyes on a crowdfunding
campaign. Think about it: if you have thirty of the most
reputable figures in an industry posting about the
same thing on social media, the combined reach is
profound. Even ten incredible influencers who have a
strong following online can make a huge impact and
generate a nice amount of traffic.
Remember that spreadsheet of press contacts we
talked about earlier? Time to open it up and add a new
tab. This time, you’re going to build a database of
social media influencers.
How to find and contact influencers
When we’re identifying potential influencers, we don’t
just look for number of followers, especially since
anyone can buy them. We look at how much
influencers’ posts are shared, and we make sure they
have an engaged following of people who are active in
conversations—liking, commenting, replying, and
retweeting.
In addition to an engaged following, we look for
those who seem to have a genuine interest in
supporting other projects. Good influencers share
other people’s posts and have a collaborative
mentality.
First, we hone in on a platform. For design projects,
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
we will usually start with Twitter because we have
seen strong conversions through it. Then we will
compile a variety of influencers, including those who
have talked about and supported similar subject
matter in the space; those who are influential in a
certain field of design; individuals who have big
followings that are somehow related or connected to
the design creators themselves; as well as founders
and creative directors of, say, design events,
institutions, organizations, schools, companies, and
startups.
Once we have a big database of possible
influencers, about two weeks before launch, we start
reaching out to them to tell them about our project
and ask if they can post about the campaign on
Launch Day. For those who write back and agree to
help, we follow up to provide them with sample
tweets for the launch. The goal of the sample tweet is
twofold: it takes the burden off of the person to come
up with their own tweet, and it gives you control of
what is being shared.
How to engage influencers in takeovers, rewards, and special
updates
For the Joan Didion campaign, we used another
influencer strategy. We offered “takeovers” to
influencers on Instagram, meaning that we invited
select participants to log into our @didiondoc account
and post on our behalf for a weekend. We promoted
the takeovers in advance, posting about the person
who would be “taking over,” to get people excited.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
Well-known magazine editors, filmmakers, writers,
and fashion stylists participated. We asked them to
share all posts they added to the @didiondoc account
to their personal accounts as well, thereby increasing
our exposure and driving a new audience to our
account. We also had influencers who created special
rewards for our campaign and wrote beautiful letters
that we shared through updates. Overall, they were all
great audience building techniques.
We have targeted influencers for several types of
campaigns through access to the product, too.
Basically, we will offer them a reward from the
campaign in exchange for a post on social media.
Offering access to the product is a huge incentive for
a social media influencer, since it allows them to get
ahead of a new trend and share a new story with their
audience. It takes extra legwork and time, but it’s
definitely worth it.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
The Campaign Before the Campaign
Maximizing pre-campaign time to build a unique beta
tester/influencer strategy
Dave Weiner, creator and founder of Priority
Bicycles, had already run two very successful
Kickstarter campaigns when he hired us to
collaborate with him on his third. Priority’s first
campaign had funded his beautifully designed,
maintenance-free, easy-to-ride, affordable bikes
(the Priority Classic), and the second one funded
the very cute children’s version (the Priority Start).
Then he hired us to help with Priority’s campaign
for its reinvention of the traditional beach cruiser,
called the Priority Coast. It would be specially
built to withstand the harsh elements at the
beach and would be rust-free. Apart from being a
beauty, it would also ride more smoothly and be
lighter than other cruisers on the market.
With time on our side (Priority hired us months
in advance), we developed a unique influencer
strategy that turned out to be really successful.
It’s unusual for a company to have products
already available before a crowdfunding
campaign, but because Priority was well-
established, they had extra prototypes built for
this purpose. We decided to actually give these
prototype bikes to a handful of carefully selected
influencers as part of our strategy.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
We identified surfers, entrepreneurs,
musicians, cyclists, athletes, and photographers
who lived near a coast and had a strong online
presence and an alignment with the Priority
Bicycles mission. Then we gave them each a bike
to try and really beat up.
Over the next few months, the beta testers
had a blast with their bikes and came back with
great reviews in monthly check-ins. Because of
their feedback, Priority even made alterations to
the bike to improve it before launching the
campaign: the handlebars were changed from a
woven leather alternative to a cork-like material,
the frame geometry was altered, the gearing and
drivetrain were modified, and more.
On Launch Day, we asked our influencers to
share their experiences on social media using our
hashtag (#findthecoast) and campaign page link,
and we retweeted them from our account. It was
a fantastic way to drive new audiences to our
campaign page and penetrate the market. The
Priority Coast campaign earned more than double
its funding goal on the first day.
On top of that, the strategy allowed the
company to make real, long-lasting connections.
The influencers in this campaign became part of
the Priority family, and that’s what crowdfunding
is all about: not just raising the funds you need,
but building a community of people who are in
your corner.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
With nearly every new campaign, we lean heavily
into an influencer strategy to leverage social media to
grow our audience, get more eyes on our campaign,
and ultimately drive funding. Often, influencers can
really help start a movement—if an influencer shares
your hashtag, for example, that can be the tipping
point for others to start using it, too.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
TAKE ON DIGITAL MARKETING: 4 TO 8+ WEEKS BEFORE
LAUNCH
In the past few years, I’ve seen digital marketing play
a bigger and bigger role in my clients’ crowdfunding
campaign strategies. Either at our suggestion or
already on their own, many of them use digital
marketing tactics—this includes email marketing,
social media marketing, search engine marketing,
online advertising, and mobile marketing—to grow,
reach, and learn about their audiences. These types of
digital marketing activities can happen before and/or
during your campaign, so you’ll want to start planning
your approach (and possibly finding a partner agency)
at least a month in advance.
Digital marketing can be an extremely useful tool
because it allows you to target and segment your
audience, as well as measure your efforts.
This is so important in crowdfunding. With usually
just 30 days to reach a goal, creators are sometimes
tempted to continually hit up their networks with
repeated emails (which contributes to one of
crowdfunding’s stigmas). But with digital marketing,
you can target the right people through a diverse set
of channels, effectively providing them with campaign
reminders without being too intrusive.
For example, in working with Will Russell, a digital
marketer we have collaborated with, we have used re-
targeting advertising, a tactic where you can reach
customers with targeted ads after they have visited a
website, signed up to a mailing list, or watched a
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
video. These customers might have clicked a link in
your newsletter and spent significant time on your
page, but ultimately didn’t pledge. Based on this
information, you can conclude that they are interested
in your product and re-target them through a different
channel, like Facebook or Twitter.
We typically begin our digital marketing campaigns
with a plan for email marketing. First, we set up an
email collection tool on the company landing page or
website. To encourage people to submit their email
addresses, we might offer exclusive access or even
product giveaways. In one recent campaign, if people
entered their email address, they were added to a
lottery for a chance to win a free product. By doing
this, we provided a clear incentive and were able to
grow our client’s mailing list.
An email list is so valuable because not only can you
now reach this audience directly via their inboxes, but
you can also upload the email list to Facebook or
another social media platform to retarget them. On
Facebook, you can also scale that valuable email list
audience by building a “Lookalike Audience,” which
essentially means you can reach additional audience
members with qualities similar to your initial audience
that Facebook finds. Facebook requires an email list of
100 addresses to build a Lookalike Audience, but it’s
ideal to start with about 500 to 1,000, if possible, so
Facebook has a larger pool of data from which to build
the audience.
On Launch Day, Will (or another digital marketing
partner) starts running paid ads on Facebook. His goal
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
is to get traffic to the campaign page and collect
valuable data to re-target the right people.
In a simple paid ad campaign, he might start with
four different ad campaigns, each with four simple
ads. Early on you’ll want to test which audiences, as
well as which ad headlines, images, and descriptions
are the most successful at getting Facebook users to
click through to your campaign (and, ultimately,
become backers). Then you’ll use your learnings from
early tests to optimize future ad campaigns.
Like everything else in crowdfunding, digital
marketing requires the patience to determine what is
working and what isn’t for your specific campaign.
There is no formula. However, if you do your due
diligence in hiring a digital marketer or take the time to
set it up yourself, it can take your campaign to the
next level. What’s great is that you don’t necessarily
need a big budget for digital marketing. Will told me
that “For less than $100 dollars, often you can get a
good understanding as to whether a particular tactic
will work for you. Digital marketing allows you to
make a small bet first, and then measure the data
from this small bet to evaluate if and how to make
bigger bets.”
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
PREPARE AN EMAIL CAMPAIGN: 4 TO 8+ WEEKS BEFORE
LAUNCH
When I talk to potential clients early on, one of the big
questions I ask is, “Do you have a mailing list?”
Why? People on your mailing list have already
actively engaged with you in some way (by signing up
to receive your emails), so they’re likely to be some of
your best supporters (including interested subscribers,
friends, family, colleagues, and more).
Generally, a client will send us their mailing list
before a campaign so we can plan to reach out to their
network in the weeks leading up to launch. Once we
receive it (usually in a CSV file), we upload it to an
email marketing tool like MailChimp.
