chunk_full:
CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN CALENDAR
Here’s a suggested timeline to help you prepare for
your campaign launch. There’s also a sample Launch
Day schedule and some tips for what to do during and
after your campaign. Every timeline will be different,
of course. There have been campaigns where we had
to accelerate the launch and didn’t put the campaign
page together until less than a week before. There
have also been times when the video wasn’t
completely finalized until minutes to launch (scary!).
This schedule is fairly conservative and is meant to be
a guide to help you get started, so it’s not a
prescription for exactly how things need to be done.
You might cross some things off your list earlier or
later. That’s okay!
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
UP TO 6 MONTHS BEFORE LAUNCH
• Assess your audience. Do you have a built-in
audience that’s shown interest in your idea?
• Set up a website or landing page for your
project, product, or business. Your key call-
to-action should be an invitation to sign up
for your mailing list.
• Set up social media accounts for your
project, product, or business. Share and
engage.
• Consider doing digital marketing for email
capture, hiring a designer, and/or sending
pre-campaign market research surveys
(especially for product and tech campaigns).
• Research the competition. Review similar
campaigns and press. Continue learning
about your audience.
• Back other projects.
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
8 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Set up your account and start your profile
and page for your crowdfunding campaign.
• Create an outline for your campaign page.
• Create a rewards wish list. Research
logistics to refine your list. Check platform
rules and resources.
• Get in touch with fulfillment partners and
look into production and shipping costs.
• Start a budget worksheet and begin tallying
costs.
• Conceptualize your video. Write a script, get
feedback on it, and finalize. Assemble your
video team.
Social media
• Start growing your followings on your social
media accounts organically and/or through

BUDGET WORKSHEET
The most important part of a budget worksheet?
Having one! Start your worksheet early (use Excel or
another program with formulas), get feedback from
colleagues and an accountant, and double- and triple-
check that you’re not missing anything. As your
campaign launch approaches, you’ll be constantly
revisiting, adjusting, and fine-tuning it depending on
your product.
None of this is set in stone, but to help guide you,
I’ve put together a sample budget for a Kickstarter
project. All of these numbers are hypothetical, and
these costs can vary rather widely. I’ve seen
campaign videos made for under $2,000 and for over
$30,000. The point is to do the math and avoid
missing anything. This worksheet is the starting point
for thinking about the kinds of costs you’ll need to
consider.

EXAMPLE 1: NASA GRAPHICS STANDARDS
MANUAL
Exclusive reissue of the National Aeronautics
and Space Administration (NASA) Graphics
Standards Manual, designed by Danne &
Blackburn, now available:
http://bit.ly/NASAmanual
In 1958, the United States Congress created
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
the National Aeronautics and Space
Administration. A young President John F.
Kennedy set the deadline of landing a man on
the moon and returning him safely to earth by
1970. Project Mercury and Apollo flights 1
through 10 brought them closer, until 1969
when Neil Armstrong succeeded and uttered
those famous words: “That’s one small step
for man, one giant leap for mankind.”
The Apollo program ended in 1972 and the
agency that went to the moon and showed us
our first image of the earth struggled to retain
the romance and urgency of its past missions.
At that time, President Richard Nixon pushed
government departments to raise the standard
of their design and communications, which
triggered the National Endowment for the Arts
(NEA’s) “Federal Graphics Improvement
Program.” One of the first targets for the NEA
program was NASA, and the NEA wanted to
get a big win on the scorecard. Shortly after, a
young and small firm in New York, Danne &
Blackburn, received a Request for Proposal
(RFP). They were eventually selected to
present a new identity to NASA.
In 1974, the partners of the firm—Richard
Danne and Bruce Blackburn—presented to
NASA administrators in Washington D.C. The
work was accepted and would be contained in
a ring binder titled the NASA Graphics
Standards Manual, an extensive document that
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
included instructions on designing every aspect
of NASA’s new identity—from letterheads to
space shuttles. The new identity, spearheaded
by a logo that would come to be known as the
“Worm,” allowed NASA’s departments a
common voice through which they could speak
as one cohesive unit.
After a less than smooth introduction by
NASA, the identity program was rolled out
across the organization. But after almost two
decades, and many challenges along the way,
NASA rescinded the Worm in 1992. The first
logo, known as the “Meatball,” was reinstated.
23 years later, Jesse Reed and Hamish
Smyth—Pentagram Associate Partners and
creators of last year’s 1970 NYCTA Graphics
Standards Manual reissue—reached out to
Danne to reissue the NASA Graphics Standards
Manual as a hardcover book. He said yes.
Smyth and Reed’s reissue is intended to be a
celebration of the great work designed by
Danne and Blackburn—brought back to earth
41 years after it was designed, and 23 years
after it was lost. Danne is in full support of the
project, which will include a foreword from the
designer and exclusive materials from the
DanneDesign archive that have never been
seen before by the public. It will also include an
essay by Christopher Bonanos (New York
magazine, Instant: The Story of Polaroid).
The reissue will only be available during the
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
length of their Kickstarter campaign. Reed and
Smyth have partnered with the crowdfunding
agency Vann Alexandra (Pono, the NYCTA
Graphics Standards Manual, Joan Didion
documentary) to run the campaign, which
launched today: http://bit.ly/NASAmanual
Speaking as a design nerd, I think the
“Worm” logo is almost perfect, and the
system behind it is a wonderful example of
modernist design and thinking. But at a
fundamental level, I think the Worm logo and
design system appropriately represents an
agency whose goal is to explore space and
push the boundaries of science. Where the
“Meatball” feels cartoon-like, cute, and old
fashioned; the Worm feels sleek, futuristic,
forward thinking. All good things for a space
agency at the bleeding edge of science and
exploration.
Hamish Smyth
The reissue will be printed using high quality scans of
Danne’s personal copy. Every page will be included,
printed with standard sheets on the right side and
section dividers on the front and backsides—
consistent with the ring-binder form of the original.
The manual provided clarity to an
organization that was built on the foundation
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
of precision, clarity, and unity. NASA didn’t
need a fresh new logo to sell products, it
needed to signal authority, giving the
collective agencies under one administration
a common voice. The program may have
been designed 41 years ago, but its
fundamental design principles are still in
practice today and I think that’s worth
preserving.
Jesse Reed
The Kickstarter campaign will run for 34 days from
September 1 through October 5, 2015. Rewards
include hardcover copies of the reissue starting at
$89, which will not be available after the campaign
ends.

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
Priority Bicycles’ Latest Kickstarter Project, The
Coast,
Funds in Just Two Hours
Rustproof beach cruiser blows initial goal out of
the water and rising.
NEW YORK, NY (March 17th, 2016)—Within
two hours of launching its latest bicycle on
Kickstarter, Priority Bicycles’ campaign for the
beautifully designed and rustproof Priority Coast
reached its initial funding goal of $30,000. By mid
afternoon the Coast had doubled its pledges and
was marked a “Project We Love” by one of the
world’s largest crowdfunding platforms.
“I am overwhelmed by the outpour of support
from the Priority community and our loyal
backers,” said Priority Bicycles founder David
Weiner. “As a socially funded company that
answers to our customers, we couldn’t be
happier with these results right out of the gate. It
reassures us that we are doing the right thing for
our consumer base and bringing a bike to the
public that is unlike anything else on the market.”
While the 100 super early bird Coast rewards
sold out in the first four hours, some standard
early bird Coast rewards are still available to
backers at $369 (regular price $449). For those
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

looking to outfit a crew or buy a fleet for company
use, the ten custom logo pack reward is available
for $3,500, a $1,990 savings.
Priority is also offering a limited edition artist
bike painted by Brooklyn-based artist Chris
Willcox. “The Priority Coast is a bicycle built for
engaging with the landscape: the sea, the surf,
and the wide-open sky,” states Willcox. “With
that in mind, I am painting a special edition bike in
a way that will invite the landscape back into it,
through a palette of aquatic and atmospheric
blues and fluid brushstrokes that echo the rhythm
of the tides that are so important to Sustainable
Coastlines Hawaii and the community.”
The Coast is the first beach cruiser truly

broken down, hard to pedal cruisers a thing of the

deliver in late June, in perfect time for summer
fun.

Email marketing is a great way to ramp up excitement

out of your email list in droves, it’s a good sign you
might be overdoing it.

In late 2014, I got an email on LinkedIn from Emma
Parry, a literary agent at Janklow & Nesbit Associates,
asking if I wanted to write “the Crowdsourceress
Book.” It wasn’t until months later that I finally got it
together and thought, Maybe I should. Thank you,
Emma, for thinking I was worthy and for your help
along the way.
I had no idea how to write a book proposal, so
through Emma I was introduced to the lovely and
amazing Eve Claxton who brought along the equally
lovely and amazing Kelly Shetron to help me craft my
words into a substantial 55-page document (beautifully
designed by Hamish). It was then that I had the
privilege of being chosen by the great Colleen Lawrie
as one of her writers at PublicAffairs.

done that without so many people. It’s to all of you

Meredith Jenks
Alex Daly is the founder of Vann Alexandra, a creative
services agency that gets projects financed through
crowdfunding, and the industry’s “Crowdsourceress,”
a name she received in the press for her expertise in
crowdfunding. Her clients include Neil Young, Oscar-
winning filmmakers, Pentagram designers, and girl
group TLC. Alex has served on panels at top film
festivals, universities, and organizations. She is in
Forbes’ class of 2016 30 under 30. This is her first
book for PublicAffairs.
Before transitioning into crowdfunding Alex was a
film producer and production manager. Before that,
she was a fact checker for New York and WSJ
magazines. Alex graduated from Vanderbilt University,
where she majored in Spanish and Philosophy and
minored in film.

PublicAffairs is a publishing house founded in 1997. It
is a tribute to the standards, values, and flair of three
persons who have served as mentors to countless
reporters, writers, editors, and book people of all
kinds, including me.
I. F. STONE, proprietor of I. F. Stone’s Weekly,
combined a commitment to the First Amendment
with entrepreneurial zeal and reporting skill and
became one of the great independent journalists in
American history. At the age of eighty, Izzy published
The Trial of Socrates, which was a national bestseller.
He wrote the book after he taught himself ancient
Greek.
BENJAMIN C. BRADLEE was for nearly thirty years the
charismatic editorial leader of The Washington Post. It
was Ben who gave the Post the range and courage to
pursue such historic issues as Watergate. He
supported his reporters with a tenacity that made
them fearless and it is no accident that so many
became authors of influential, best-selling books.
ROBERT L. BERNSTEIN, the chief executive of Random
House for more than a quarter century, guided one of
book_title: The Crowdsourceress: Get Smart, Get Funded, and Kickstart Your Next Big Idea

chunk_full:
the nation’s premier publishing houses. Bob was
personally responsible for many books of political
dissent and argument that challenged tyranny around
the globe. He is also the founder and longtime chair of
Human Rights Watch, one of the most respected
human rights organizations in the world.
For fifty years, the banner of Public Affairs Press was
carried by its owner Morris B. Schnapper, who
published Gandhi, Nasser, Toynbee, Truman, and
about 1,500 other authors. In 1983, Schnapper was
described by The Washington Post as “a redoubtable
gadfly.” His legacy will endure in the books to come.
Peter Osnos, Founder and Editor-at-Large
